Recommended
32.7 hrs on record
Posted: 20 December, 2018
I have been on a journey playing through all of the Assassin's Creed games in order. This one has been completed, faster than any previous ones in terms of how many weeks it took. I tended to take breaks, but I was completely hooked with this one and completed it pretty much the same week I started it. I have a 77% total sync, and even though I have started up Origins already, I do plan on playing this one more at a later date to finish. The main story was completed.

Performance was great. I was running near max at 4K resolution averaging 50fps which for me is perfectly playable. I run an i7 4790k, GTX 1080 and 16GB DDR3 RAM. The game is very beautiful to look at, although not sure if it really beats out Unity. So this takes home the 2nd place prize out of the AC games (prior to this one).

Gameplay was very much improved, having a grappling hook type gun to help get around (actual name of the gun fades me at the moment). It helps to traverse up large buildings within seconds, and can also cast a line between buildings at fairly long distances to travel across. It helped even more to get away from enemies. And in regards to enemies...

This game felt much easier to evade enemies than previous in the series. With that hook gun I tended to get away from them fairly quickly without even having to use a smoke bomb. I suppose this is a positive though, as an Assassin you should be able to vanish fairly quickly. And the hook gun is pretty much an alternative to the smoke bomb.

Unlike previous entries, you won't be able to purchase any properties or buildings or anything. Instead, you are building up your gang through a set of skill trees. It does contain purchasing stores for increased income, but it is very simplified as its just a passive skill you buy and nothing visual within the city itself.

But where it simplified property buying, it went more in depth with the RPG mechanics. You have a max of 10 levels for your characters. You do play 2 different characters, male and female, and they each have their own skill tree. They are the exact same aside from a couple skills at the end of the tree. If you gain a skill point playing the male, you also gain one with the female that she can spend. Max level is 10, and you gain levels by spending points you earn from xp. Little backwards from usual with RPGs, but it works well. By time you reach level 10 you will have every single skill purchased in each skill line. Equipment also has stats and level requirements, and some you have to craft, but all around fairly simple with not a crazy amount of options. But it was good.

The amount of activities in this one seemed to be more so than others. From cargo escorts, fight clubs, cargo hijacks, templar hunts, bounty hunting with kidnapping, freeing child labor from factories, carriage races, and many famous people to do side quests for, it was really loaded with content outside of just collecting items. And it was all enjoyable. I had a lot of fun with all of it, and still have side quests to complete.

All in all, I give this one a 9.5 out of 10. The only reason I give it a .5 less is you must spend real money to be able to see a couple of the collections on the map. Yes, you could run around and find them or use Google, but Google is not a part of the game so it is not taken into consideration. Just the fact the microtransactions like that are in a single player game is a small turn off for me. But this is still one of my favorites in the series along with Unity and Black Flag.

Posted: 19 November, 2015
Great Performance on a GTX 980 and an i7 4790K with 8GB of Ram! Well I mean if you wanna max out Nvidia style, well good luck maybe you'll acheive 60fps in 2016. The game will drop to 40fps in the first mission with GW on. So do yourself a favor. Use only HBAO+ because HBAO+Ultra takes 10fps, yeah you heard right. And Turn off PCSS/PCSS ULTRA. With PCSS you loose 20fps and with PCSS Ultra 35fps. So basicly I'm running the game with PCSS off, HBAO+ , 2xTXAA and everything else on max. Averaging 70-80fps with ease.

I'd say it's a great optimized game so far. The only bad thing once again is Nvidia and nothing else. So just turn those 'features' off and enjoy a great game!

To me Assassins Creed has been held up by three distinct pillars: Free Running, Combat, Story. If one doesn't hold up, the game is screwed.

A good story is really all just preferential anyways. but I haven't played an AC story I don't like.

The combat. Well it's terrible. It is nothing like what Assassins Creed was all these years. As I said the animations are stiff and feel like they are stuck in "fast-forward" mode. And you get practically zero choice in weaponry.

If none of these issues bother you then be my guest and grab Syndicate. Otherwise this is the first Assassins Creed game (and I've played nearly all of them) I could NOT recommend.

25.0 hrs on record
Posted: 10 February, 2020
WARNING! This review may perspectively contain indirect spoilers!

Introduction
The story is set in Victorian era in London (1868, to be specific) during the great industrial revolution. This time, you play as two twin assassins, the calculating and stealthy Evie, and the hot-blooded and straight-to-battle Jacob Frye. The mission is simple, stop the ruling hand of Templars in London and defeat the crew pulling the strings.

Personal view
The story itself was pretty mediocre, not great, but not necessarily bad, it was the typical - climb the villain ladder and kill off the atagonist. There was really no character development, although the characters themselves were interesting, nothing too generic and common. The origin of characters are also missing, I do not know anything about Evie or Jacob, only that their father was an assassin and he liked to give wise quotes.

Apart from story, what really caught my attention is, of course, the enviroment and "atmosphere". In-game London was immersive and I really felt like I was roaming the 19th century. It is my first expirience to actually see children in a video game (especially PG-18â¢ rated one), which adds to the immersion, because sadly, child labor was very common in this era - working in factories under unacceptable conditions for long hours. But except for this depressing fact, the population is very lively and active, they react to what you do. The map is very huge (I believe about 30% bigger than Unityâs Paris), so thankfully, they added horses and carriages to drive you around faster.

As for equipments. you have various revolvers to choose from as firearms, and as for melee - Kukri, Cane-Sword and Knuckles. Other than that you have throwing knifes, voltaic bombs, smoke bombs and med-kits. You are also equiped with a grappling hook (made by the great A. G. Bell), which has made traveling from roof-to-roof much easier!

As Evie and Jacob arrive to London, Jacob gets the great idea of creating a gang called "The Rooks". There are enemy gangs all around the London, the more boroughs you conquer, the safer the streets to travel. Your gang members always greet you, and offer you help, by getting recruited. You can recruit up to 5 gang members.

In conclusion, if you are looking for an Assassins Creed game set in 19th century, which has an amazing map and enviroment to interact with, and donât mind a more or less clichÃ© story - it is a game just for you.

Pros & Cons
+ Characters, not developed, but interesting (Evie, Jacob, Starrick, love âem).
+ Enviroment, the city is beautiful!
+ Graphics
+ Optimization - Medium settings; 30-50 fps (avg. 48, 1% of time bellow 30); on a Intel Core i5
4460; NVIDIA GeForce GTX 960 (2GB VRAM); 8GB RAM.
So if you have a newer budget rig, you should not worry.
+ Awesome combat combos.
+ Traveling methods (horses and the grappling hook).

- Story, it was not bad, but there was alot of unused potentional for such rich historic era.
- Climbing, not entirely, but there were moments when the game decided doing the opposite of what I was doing, and it was frustrating.

Additional info
Finishing the story, with minimal side-questing = ~ 21 hours

This is not really a spoiler, but it is a nice addition to the game. I will still mark it as spoiler just in case, because I sure was surprised to discover this feature. 

Just so you are not confused - With every 1,000 epx, you get a skill point, and to level up your character, you have to spend those points. The higher the level you are, the more skill points you have to spend.

Conquer 3 boroughs (basically neighborhoods) to unlock senquence 9.

Amazing game, highly recommend it!

45.6 hrs on record
Posted: 23 June, 2020
This game is not terrible. That's how you should decide. Do you want to pay 20+ Euro on a game that is "not terrible"?

Here's the thing. Nothing in the game is truly memorable. There are only two missions I really remember, the Intro tutorial mission because everything was new and I was excited to be playing Assassins Creed again (I used to be a fan in the good old Ezio times), and the first real assassination mission because I learned some new game mechanics. It's unfortunate really because the story has potential and the main characters are interesting. But the game doesn't capitalise on it and instead you find yourself with an underwhelming feeling of meaninglessness every time you finish a mission. There were a couple of great plot twists that kept me going but even then, as soon as the cut scene finishes you're back in town, earned another few experience points and unlocked a new weapon without any significant impact on gameplay. No real sense of reward. No 60 seconds to get out of the place before it explodes, or being trapped until you find the secret exit, or anything like that, which makes you feel disconnected from the mission as soon as it's done.
The cut scenes are short and repetitive and they fail to build up tension. I think maybe this is the biggest problem here. If you don't care much for the story and just enjoy climbing walls and killing targets from above, then this game is great! the free running flows (thanks to the infamous grappling hook) and the fighting mechanics are not bad. You can do combo hits and if you time your strikes you do more damage which is always satisfying.
But the assassinations don't give you that sense of achievement or reward, they are not challenging, they lack a sense of progress. The story is clumsy and the missions feel disconnected. There are too many characters and you don't really feel drawn to them.

Some side missions however are quite fun, where the only way to do them is by not getting detected, which to me has always been the heart of the game. Stealth mechanics are decent and stealth kills do feel rewarding.

Only play it if you're a fan of the saga and if it's on sale for less than a fiver

Syndicate is not as good as AC2, at all. I'm bored in this game.

Am I going to finish it? Probably yes, I paid 40 bucks for it so I'll try. But I already have to force myself because sometimes it's just painfully dumb and stupid.

The main review was written at 50hrs / 45% progress, edited after I completed main game in a little under 100 hrs (I did some idling though to generate money, still not enough to buy / upgrade all gear) and standalone DLC Jack the Ripper that took me another 10-15 hours.

I am a huge AC brand fan and didn't miss a single game apart from Valhalla and Odyssey (which is next on my list). I grew up on rather depressing Altair story and lived through revered Ezio d'Auditore's life and yes, like many, this set a bar this brand is yet to reach again. AC3 was a shocking meh, Black Flag was probably 3rd best (although quite different), Unity was aight and Rogue was okay but a bit outdated by the time it got released. I also played Origins and that was - simply put - different. Obviously, this trend remained and AC is no longer the brand it used to be - whether it's influence of Witcher 3 or change in leadership at Ubisoft, I cannot say.. but it's fair to say that Syndicate is an epitaph (or epilogue if you like) to Assassin's Creed as we knew it.

And now finally to the game - how is it you may ask? Well, it's not as bad as I thought it would be. See, after terribly optimised Unity this game came up with a new feature - two heroes between whom you can freely choose (something I prefer over having to choose one permanently -> Odyssey). When I go back to dated reviews, claims were protagonists were boring / annoying and that game itself was pretty dull.

But no, these two new protagonists are not another Ratonhkake:ton (sorry for my spelling, lazy to google it and don't remember it that well). Yes, Jacob is a bit annoying with his rebelling nature at first, but Evie is sympathetic to me and I prefer to play for her during my free world wandering (this interestingly changed in the second half of the game where I switched and preferred Jacob). They both have their differences and they bicker a lot, something I wish I could change (just like when your parents are about to divorce and you cannot do anything but watch) but eventually all ends well to my satisfaction. Both of characters have slightly different skill trees you can fully unlock by the time you reach 50% of game (provided you collect treasures, do side activities and so on) and it makes you pretty bad ass early in the game.

Second new feature, which I personally enjoy since GTA: San Andreas times, are gangs of New York London! Just like when you are liberating camps in Far Cry series and get random friendlies spawn around those territories, same was implemented here and I kinda like it. I don't like it to the point where I would have a gang follow me while I am ziplining through the city but they have their situational use and controlling 'rooks' is easy.

These were big game changers for the brand but going forward in time, it was nothing in comparison to Origins. Now for the quick summary for those who don't like to read long sentences:

Pros:
+ Industrial London
+ Two switchable protagonists
+ Gangs feature
+ Riding shotgun / stagecoaches!
+ Wide variety of historic figures (it's nothing new yet still entertaining)
+ Train base with memorabilias
+ Last 'true' Assassin's Creed
+ Less of Shaun and other "present" assassins (although you cannot escape them completely)
+ Boats and trains for you to travel on
+ Hook for slightly faster traversing through the city

Cons:
- Main story is slightly 'meh' and uninteresting
- additionally, the newest artifact from First Civ is BOOORING
- achievement for hitting 5k destructibles
- Jacob is occasionally really ignorant, their arguing is especially irritating mid-late game
- number of bugs and glitches including game breaking issues that were never fixed
- DLCs are atrocious, scenes do not trigger, bugs after bugs just terrible optimisation in comparison to main game
- Indian assassin Henry (sorry pal, you're lame)
- the fate of 'modern timeline' was never explained in following games, all the buildup since AC2 about Juno and sages was squashed in some comics - super FAIL
- WW1 timezone was too big and felt out of the place

Overall I can say that I have enjoyed playing this game (apart from seldom bugs) slightly more than I did Unity and I weep with a thought that from this point onwards, we'll just play poorly presented variation of Witcher 3 clones with typical Ubisoft features.


Ad: Jack the Ripper standalone DLC (will contain spoilers!)

This came up with a familiar territory in different colours (fall 1888) and a story about gruesome killer - Jack the Ripper. I have expected the return of investigative missions I so much enjoyed in Unity but nope, not at all. You get a lame-ass story about Jack being a former assassin who went nuts (I still don't understand what triggered his hatred for assassins when it was templars who killed his mother) and corrupted Rooks. You also get to play for him in a number of missions, something I have suffered through due to him being so annoying character. I'd rather play for Rodrigo Borgia or some other villain who had a bit of charisma!

Pros:
+ just about right in size and content
+ wide variety of side missions, including a number of new missions
+ limited option of gear, you are not flooded like you were in main game
+ economy is nonexistent, making gear upgrades super easy
+ investigative sections of main plot missions
+ Jacob survives

Cons:
- You don't get to play for Jacob (which I intended to)
- Evie gets older and indian-ish but does not look the same!!
- Jack the Ripper character and his missions
- recycled dialogs,you often listen same lines / voice across - different missions
- recycled models (Arthur Weaversbrook is Benjamin Disraeli in a hat etc)
- what happened to Henry?? After marrying Evie, I'd expect him to come with his wife...
- still a large number of glitches (exploding stagecoaches, random resetting / insta-failing missions)
- absolutely atrocious fighting effects (Evie no longer kills, she stuns enemies with indian wristbands but no one bother to change animation for hidden blade fighting style)
- returning Rosetta Stone to rightful owners in Egypt in one side mission - what? Without English scientists we would know nothing what hieroglyphs are so â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ pls


As standalone DLCs go, Dead Kings was so much better!

Overall score: 6/10
Technically recommended, although itâs defenitely not the best Assassinâs Creed game.

I have been a huge Assassinâs Creed fan since 2009 after playing the masterpiece that is Assassinâs Creed II. However, due to the bad reputation of this game, it was not until 2020 that I finally played it for the first time. Now I understand why it has such mixed reactions... because mine is one of them.

First, the good...

Gameplay - 9/10
A lot of fun and makes the game actually worth playing. It has enough variety for a truly assassin oriented game, in order to not feel excessively repetitive. I honestly didnât feel that the controls during combat and free-running/parkour were any clunkier than they usually are in an Assassinâs Creed game - although this has always annoyed me. The combat system is not the best in the franchise, but also not the worst, and itâs very easy to master. It is, at times, pretty frustrating because it can be unresponsive - more so than in previous installments. For some reason triggering finishers, especially group finishers, is hard to achieve. The movements are very fast, which I like, but the combat animations themselves as well as the ragdoll physics arenât the best, and there is almost no blood. The stealth system is fun and easy. The parkour system is also excellent, even better with the ability to zipline between the enormous buildings, making exploration both fun and immersive. The rope launcher also adds a really cool stealth mechanic with the ability to return to rooftops extremely quickly after swooping down for stealthy air assassinations.

Graphics - 8/10
Although not as high quality as Unity, I still found the graphics of this game to be really nice for a 2015 game (excluding Witcher 3).

Performance - 8/10
Decent performance given the quality of the graphics, with occasional frame drops and very short, temporary freezes only in demanding combat situations. However, my graphics card being six years old, this was actually surprisingly better than expected. I think the game has been decently optimized but it could be better.

Setting/Time Period - 7/10
Victorian England, from the surroundings to the people all around, felt extremely immersive. London is an absolute pleasure to explore, with realistically sized buildings that really make you feel you are there. However, the time period itself is not exactly the most exciting one in the franchise and also the somber looking city, accurately portrayed for its time period, is not the most beautiful to look at.

Soundtrack - 9/10
Beautiful and appropriate for the setting. Unlike other assassinâs creed games, the songs are actually new instead of being recycled versions of the same Assassinâs Creed II melody.

And now the really, really bad...

Plot - 0/10
Probably the worst plot in the entire assassinâs creed franchise. Contrived, predictable, illogical and boring. Throughout the story, the male protagonist is demeaned as much as possible in order to exalt the female protagonist as much as possible in exchange, with very forced, obvious tropes all over. The entire story felt more like a parody or a mockery of the franchise, especially of its own main character featured in the gameâs cinematic trailer. There were numerous missed opportunities to improve his character development. Having dual protagonists was terribly executed. Greatly disappointing.

Characters - 4/10
The male protagonist, Jacob Frye, is a deeply flawed, relatable, fun assassin, with an amazing sense of humor, sharp wit, upbeat attitude and really badass, lore friendly skills. Overall, he is a breath of fresh air among too many uptight, serious, boring characters. He is also young, reckless, immature, brash, cocky, rebellious and appears to be the black sheep of his family. He has serious father issues. Like all trained assassins, Jacob is adept at stealth, but he doesnât actually excel at it - he does, however, excel greatly in combat. He is thrilled at being an assassin and is very enthusiastic about it, unlike many other assassinâs creed protagonists. Jacobâs voice actor is amazing. As a character, Jacob Frye is on par with Edward Kenway of Assasinâs Creed IV Black Flag due to having very similar personality traits and character flaws. However, in this story he is portrayed horribly, unfortunately, and because the plot and the writing in general were so bad, his character development was seriously hampered. He is portrayed as the cliched âdumb little brotherâ of the female protagonist, Evie Frye, who in turn is portrayed as the cliched know-it-all âwise older sisterâ - and theyâre twins. In contrast to Jacob, Evie has absolutely NO character flaws whatsoever and is the âbestâ at everything. She has the wisdom of an assassin Mentor when sheâs just as young as Jacob, who she treats like garbage constantly. She has a ridiculously overpowered invisibility skill that is totally anti-lore and unexplained. She has no personality and is constantly getting highly praised by tons of characters and is liked by everyone that isnât an antagonist - in other words, sheâs a Mary Sue. All the flaws went to the male and none to the female. As a woman who strongly believes in gender equality, I was very disappointed. The assassinâs creed franchise needs realistic and believable female protagonists with flaws, complexity, and a personality. Lastly, in this game there is also a complete absence of interesting and memorable side characters and villains. The main villain, Crawford Starrick, was very generic. Only Jacob Frye contrasted all the boring, contrived, one-dimensional characters.

So, in conclusion...

If you play Assassinâs Creed games for the gameplay and immersion and NOT for the story or characters, by all means, play this game - itâs a lot of fun! But if you need a well written story that actually makes sense, doesnât put you to sleep, and has memorable characters, play Black Flag or the Ezio trilogy instead.

Posted: 27 September, 2017
I played the original Assassin's Creed back in 2007. That game wowed me. The ability to climb ANY building? And I could be this cool ninja-like hooded killer that could coordinate just HOW he wanted to assassinate a target? Wow!

I played Assassin's Creed 2 in 2009. That game wowed me. They improved every mechanic from the first Assassin's Creed. I loved where it was going. The story was AMAZING! I felt a sense of progression as if I was growing up with Ezio Auditore (the assasssin in that game). We were with him from the moment of his birth to the moment of his death.

I played Assassin's Creed 4 in 2013. That game wowed me. They removed the ability to kill a target any way you wanted but in its stead, they allowed you to explore the open seas of the Caribbean. In addition, the story was amazing. Just like Ezio's story, the story in Assassin's Creed IV had progression to it. The person you were and the state of the world in the beginning of the game changes durastically by the end. It also tied some loose ends from AC3 that lingered.

Now, I come to this game. I am not wowed. In fact, I am disgusted by this game. For one, Ubisoft charges you REAL WORLD CURRENCY to buy virtual money. Yeah, you remember the money you had to earn in AC2, 3, 4? You can now just pay a low fee of $30 for 100,000 in game money. The money doesn't even get you anything special. You buy things just like you could in AC2 (medicine, bullets, etc).

The story in this game is absolute trash as well. The Jacob Frye voice actor sounds like a random guy they picked off the streets. "Hey buddy, if we bought you a pint, would you like to do the voiceover in our game?" The guy overexaggerates EVERYTHING he says. On top of that, the story seems to be going nowhere. The plot established from the first game is long gone. There is no sense of mystery. However, that is not because questions were answered. If anything, questions were UNANSWERED from the ending of Assassin's Creed 3. It doesn't seem to progress anything. It's just another Assassin's vs Templar's story with no ultimate end in sight.

That doesn't mean everything in this game sucks. In fact, the environment is AMAZING. The size of London as well as the beautiful graphics really captivates my eye. Unfortunately, the animation for both running and combat is trash. It looks like a game for babies where you're controlling Mr. Wiggles (I don't know what character that is, it just sounds like a character that wiggles his arms everywhere until he hits someone). The running animations look like they were ripped from 2004's Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas multiplayer mode.

I really wanted to like this game. I wanted to find a semblance to AC1 or AC2 but they've lost the plot. Ubisoft has lost the plot, guys. They plan on releasing a new AC game in 2018 so let's hope to heck they get on with the plot.

I give this game a 6/10 - it's a great game on its own but it doesn't live up to the hype of the Assassin's Creed series. They should have made this a spin-off series called 'Creed of Assassins' or something. At least then I'd understand it's a story taking place in the Assassin's Creed universe and not an actual continuation of the story.

Not Recommended
81.8 hrs on record
Posted: 7 December, 2015
Trying really hard to enjoy this game.

I can look past the numerous bugs and glitches. In the past games, there have also been bugs and glitches. Some were very frustrating, and others were just design flaws. However, assassin's creed takes a grip on you. It tells you "just one more assassination mission. Just one." Well, you're not longer an assassin in this game. Now you're just some criminal.

I can look past the repetitive fetch-quests that litter the game. In past assassin's creed titles, fetch quests meant a unique dagger or sword that employed unique animations. It meant an outfit that looked very different from everything else. It meant real bonuses, payments for your hard work. This game doesn't reward you in the same way. Did you finish tediously leaping about gardens, trying to find pressed flowers for someone? Good. Here's a new color for the outfits you already have. Did you finish collecting bogus music boxes? Oh good, here's an outfit that looks like someone forgot to color it. It even glitches on its own - and in the case of this outfit, they treat the glitching as a feature, not a bug.

It doesn't motivate me to move on to another fetch-quest.

I can look past the wonky controls. In past titles, it could mean odd camera angles that make things difficult because forward command suddenly becomes right, or left, or down. Or it could mean running past a ladder and suddenly your character does a 90 degree turn and starts to climb it. But the controls have always been a problem for the assassin's creed franchise. The freedom you get with how you can move through the game, also limits the paths you can take while doing so. That's fine, if perhaps annoying.

I can look past a lot of things.

And now there will be some spoilers. You should not read further if you're senstive to such. I am not revealing story plots here by definition, but some characters will be revealed (they're not surprises, so it shouldn't matter) and some gear (which you'll get almost at the very beginning).

Right off the bat, yes bat, as in batman - you get batman gear. Batman gear, really? You get this rope launcher thing that allows you to zip across roofs. And you get it by looting it off of a bad guy. Right after you take it to Graham Bell (yeah I know) you get a quest where it can be used. Upon your return, your sibling and mister Bell explains that they just so happened to get their hands on another one. Aright, you think. So myself and the bad guys have rope launchers.

No you don't. You and your sibling does. Because apparently, the bad guys in this game think rope launchers are impractical, so no one but you and your sister has them. In spite of you looting off of a low level boss type. The lowly gang leader has one, but not the templars? Please stop hurting my narrative, Ubisoft.

Assassin's creed have always been about alternative stories to explain historical events. Ezio had a gun, and a flying machine! But you could accept that. The story explains how and why they work. I question the rope launcher - because I don't get it. How does it launch? Gun powder? But it has an infinite number of shots. Not even connor could use his ropes an infinite number of times, and his were so short that they were retrievable. Is the launcher using gas? How? By what technological marvel during 1868 is it propelling this thick metal arrow that for some reason can fasten to anything, AND hold your weight?

The parkour skills are there so you can be able to traverse buildings and alike with relative ease. Yet this is not enough? You get a rope launcher? Ubisoft is crazy for fetch quests. How about making it so you have to put up ropes and lines yourself, which you can use thereafter to traverse buildings? Why a rope launcher? How does thi fit in? I mean what's in the next assassin's creed game? A jetpack during ww1? How about a teleporting device during ww2 and your own UFO by the Vietnam war? It's not a big issue, but it contributes to lower the score of this game.

You meet five famous individuals (at least as far as I have played) leaping about London at the same time, handing out quests like they're candy at halloween. It's too much. I mean, when Da Vinci popped up in Ezio's story, assassin's creed was really balancing on the knife edge of credibility already. You could accept it historically though, because Da Vinci was involved with Medici, and so is Ezio. Da Vinci did have theories on flight, so you can buy that idea as well. But in this game? No... Just no. Charles Darwin, Graham Bell, Karl Marx, Charles Dickens, Florence Nighingale... All mashed into 1868 London and all just happen to have numerous quests to dish out to you, the leader of the Rooks - a criminal gang?

And then there's the bogus quest stories, like events where I am supposed to chase someone whom I can see is being fast forwarded in order to escape me. Not even joking, this was an old man and he outruns me, an assassin trained parkour expert, in the prime of my youth and at my physical peak. Really? He just outruns me, like that? If you don't chase him, he slows down to the normal hobbling of an old man, but if you get close, he's fast forwarded. This is unacceptable for a modern game. Hypnotism? Again - not joking here. It's not only hypnotism, hypnotism I can handle. The change of someone's behavior through methodical influence during hypnotism has been documented, if not proven. But this isn't clinical hypnotism, but cartoon hypnotism. Pendulum in the street and everything. Ghosts? No, really. I am not joking. They have ghosts. Am I playing Assassin's Creed: Scooby Do goes to London? What on earth possessed Ubisoft to allow such a corruption of their own franchise?

And talking about assassin's creed. What about the actual creed that assassin's follow? Where you simply aren't allowed to kill innocents? In this game, if I shoot two civilians with a gun, I desynchronize. However, if I hijack a carriage as if this was GTA 1860, I can run over the entire population with no consequences.

And the population; non believable drones walking back and fourth, occasionally stopping to stab one another to death. Yep, that's apparently common in London 1868. Maybe that's why no one really cares if you gun down a dozen people in the street. I mean - not even the middle ages when you played Altair was this bloody. You build up your own team that has absolutely zero function for you as an assassin. If you do bring allies, they will always ruin you being an assassin. You can even hire street kids to do your bidding. However, these are special street kids, who enjoy living in the gutter, stealing to survive. How do I know? Because after you've recruited them, you can get items from them. What items do the street kids have you ask? You'd think a pocket watch. Maybe someone stole a purse with a few cash in them? You'd be gravely mistaken. These kids are sporting 60 units of metal, 50 units of cloth, which they willingly give to you. Now, I know what you're thinking - how much is a unit? Well I don't know. But I do know one of them handed me 5000 cash, which is enough to say... Buy a bar in the game. Or several weapons. Or refeill your gear numerous times. This street kid hands it over with a smile on his face though. Totally believable and doesn't ruin your immersion one bit.

No. It ruins several bits. Several bits and some bobs in fact.

It's... I... There are no words for the atrocity that this game is. At first I thought; well, I paid good money for this game. I am at least going to finish it. After all, I did pay for it. But then my logic kicked in and I thought; so, if I finish this game, I will have both lost money AND time? You can always get more money. But you can never get more time. Time is the only finite resource in your life, of which you will always have less and less and less.

So no. I won't finish this game.
And neither should anyone else.

Don't buy this.

With Assassinâs Creed Syndicate Ubisoft once again took a step back, this time also due to the badly rated (but still underrated) Unity. But was that really necessary?

Well, no. Performance issues aside, Unity was a great game with some real innovative elements (as far as Assassinâs Creed is concerned anyway) and gorgeous graphics. With Syndicate Ubisoft seemed to undo all of that, while also trying out some new things that would be used in the later sequels.
So gone were the beautiful graphics. Now they merely got the job done. Nothing groundbreaking, but at least it ran fine on most of the systems it released on.
Assassinâs Creed Syndicate is by no means a terrible or uninspired game, unlike Rogue, but just a decent one that seems to things mostly by the numbers.

Gone is the extremely detailed city of Paris, instead making room for the more plain, but bigger and higher city of London. Iâm indifferent to this one, but I prefer a more detailed and smaller city for sure.
Gone are the more open ways to assassinate a target with it now focusing on a more linear approach instead. Terrible choice.
What has been added are the two playable characters Jacob and Evie, each with their own set of skills. Jacob is more focused on direct combat while Evie is more focused on stealth. A very good addition to the series!
A rope launcher has been added to the arsenal for quick traveling upwards and/or getting in and out (but mostly out) of conflict quickly. Also a good addition as it takes away some unnecessary or unwanted climbing; sometimes you just donât feel like climbing up, especially with the higher buildings in London.
There are now gang territories that can be conquered. A fun addition that also fits the city of London, but not a very novel one.
Combat has been a little sped up and there are some other small, new features and changes. I think Iâve discussed the most noteworthy ones, but feel free to let me know if I missed out on important stuff.

Multiplayer hasnât returned, but we didnât expect it to. Co-op has also been removed instead focusing solely on the single player portion. A weird choice since a 2 player campaign co-op would be ideal. And especially now that you have two entirely different characters to play with.

Ubisoft has never managed to match the graphics of Unity ever again. Instead they opted for a style that would run on most of the systems, thereby steadily increasing the userbase I assume. The graphics absolutely suffice. London is a nice place to play in, but it was a little too dark for my own taste. I canât really remember seeing any or a lot of sunshine. However, the animations and details of the buildings and environments were as beautiful as all of the other entries in the franchise.
Voice acting, music and effects were also strong as ever.

Assassinâs Creed Syndicate would be the last Assassinâs Creed game to do it by the numbers. This was a decent game, with a good story and a few innovations, but nothing that would blow your mind. I personally experienced it as a step back when compared to Unity.
Anyway, following this game would be a new take on the series and it would return two years later instead of the usual annual releases. Its name: Assassinâs Creed Origins. See you next time!

28.7 hrs on record
Posted: 3 February, 2016
At a glance
Game Name: Assassin Creed Syndicate
Original Release: 19 November 2015
Genre Tags: Stealth, Parkour, Assassin, Open-World
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime: +-16 hours Main Story
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; those intrigued by the genre; fans of Assassin Creed series


Assassins Creed Syndicate is the very first modern Assassins Creed ever created. When you think London in the middle of 1868, London is in the middle industrial revolution and it is only 75 years away from French revolution. However it feels like a thousand years has passed, because it completely changes people how they live.


Story
Introducing two main protagonists, Jacob and Evie, they will fight back free up London using their street gangs. Jacob and Evie have to gather people to take down the Templars.
I wonât spoil the story but I can tell you that youâll learn many of historical stories which are a lot more interesting than your school. Starring Charles Darwin, Karl Max, Alexander Graham bell, Queen Victoria and many more Syndicate manages to deliver a cohesive and satisfying tale.


Gameplay
The gameplay has been polished a lot, seems like the developer has learned a lot from the previous series.


Combat
In Syndicate, developers also revamp the combat system. Back then, London, in 1868, is the time of concealed weapon. Back in the time, 70 years before was Medieval time period. Weapon was to have a sword, axe, and etc. But now in London 1868, London is not possible to do that. Therefore the combat is more to street combat style where everything has been brought into close quarters. Syndicate focuses on melee combat, with Jacob and his street gang pulling enemies into fist fights on the city streets. Combat is no less brutal than in previous games, but bringing fights between you and your enemies closer allows for some seriously cool-looking cinematic kills. They are faster and more brutal than ever. Thanks to weapons like the brass knuckles.

Countering, Chain kills, Double kills, Enemy shields, Disarming, Hiring, Cinematic kills, Weapon toss, Variety of projectiles, and etc have been brought back. But, combat using the hidden blade like in Assassin Creed 2 or brotherhood has not been brought back. Itâs only being used for the finishing move.

Navigation
London buildings are taller and wider than any features in the series before. Syndicate introduces the rope launcher (a tool that probably the game changer of the game), which lets Jacob and Evie rapidly ascend to high ledges and create ziplines across wide gaps to help them quickly get around these larger spaces. Player can use it almost in any building that they want.

The way how you switch your character is just like GTA V, you can freely switch whenever you want from the Menu. You are in open world; it is your choice to play whether you want to play as Jacob or Evie. However, within the main sequences/chapters, whichever you want to refer to, this world will alternate between the two depending on the story what you want to tell. In addition, what make it more fun is the perks/upgrades is different within each other.

Stealth
Whistling is also back, is just as useful as ever, as we found when we used it to lure a gang member to our hiding spot for a quick, clean kill from cover.
The Hood toggle works beautifully. While you are in the stealth mode you will always have your hood on. When you are walk freely or not in the stealth mode, you can have your hood away.

Vehicle
This is the big part of Syndicate. Thinking of London in 1868, London has âThe Carriageâ. The player can steal the vehicle and even hijack it. Player also can ride on it; hide in it and even fight on the top. The carriage is a powerful tool for the player to navigate freely. But be aware that enemy can also use it to against you.

Street Gang
Just almost like in Brotherhood series where you can hire your Assassins brotherhood. Instead of that, in Syndicate you can hire your gang to fight with you.


Graphic
As you explore the magnificence of London city in the 19 Century, it makes you want to pack up your stuffs immediately and fly to London. Sky-high towers, stone walkways line the financial center, galloping horse carriage, red-box telephone, homeless burn fires in trash cans in alleys, stations bustle with passengers and passing trains, London feels alive. Itâs breath-taking.

The character design is really sharp. Looking at the white silky smooth beard of Charles Darwin in the highly detailed graphic makes you want to try to pull his beard or burn it.

The lighting in this game is absolutely amazing. Everything looks believable, they are using HDR effect to slowly blend in the darker place to the brighter place; you can see from indoor to outdoor, the outdoor is very bright. As you are going out, the brightness will slowly blend in to normal brightness. In other hand, from brighter place to darker place, you can from outdoor to indoor; the room started with very dark lighting and slowly blends in to normal brightness. Honestly, this is one of best looking open-world; everything looks amazing, the buildings, the shadow, the texture, the detail, are astounding.


Sound System
Talking about music, because in Assassins Creed 3 the music was almost dead all the time. In Syndicate, as player move throughout the city, you will hear different ambient music. For instance, in the street you could hear people playing violin, or, if you are in the pop music place, you could hear pop music. It is really nice to have this idea in the game because it reflexes different feeling where you are in. Thanks to Austin Wintory, a great grammy-nominated Journey composer for creating awesome music background for Syndicate. You are not far from Jesper Kyd.


Replayability
Both the story missions and the open-world activities work better than previous series. It isnât perfect, but with such a beautiful city, a genuinely likeable cast of characters, and many improvements to both stealth and combat this feels like a step in the right direction for Assassinâs Creed. You can stick with this game for hundreds of hours to finish it on 100% sync memories.


Problems
1. Some random crash and freeze screen sometimes happens.
2. To running on 60 fps with everything on maximum setting, you really need strong pc specs. Even if you are running on GTX 970 or AMD R9 380 GPU with core i5 6600K CPU, you probably still need to struggle lowering down the display setting.
Taking core i7 is highly recommended and gets the higher GPU probably.
3. Currently SLI is not that beneficial.

Hopefully they will release next patch soon to fix all the problems.

Not Recommended
45.9 hrs on record
Posted: 26 February, 2017
As an avid Assassin's Creed fan, AC Syndicate is a major disappointment. I had expected that the folks at Ubisoft to actually learn from their mistakes (Unity) and strive to make a better AC experience in through Syndicate. After giving this game so many chances to prove itself, ultimately it is still a major letdown by Ubisoft.

1) Controls are still very wonky and stiff
= Parkour are super-smooth and semi-realistic (if you would excuse all the extreme parkour of course), but the controls for the game was not improved. It is still wonky and stiff in execution, which leads to frustrating movements and maneuvers.

2) Uninspiring main characters
= Jacob and Evie Frye is still likeable, just not inspiring. Most of the dialogues are dull, with Evie sticks mostly to the plan and Jacob being sarcastic and relaxed in an almost lazy way. Interaction with other characters within the game are similarly dull and not exciting. Truly a missed opportunity especially when you have historical figures like Charles Darwin, Alexander Graham Bell and Karl Marx walking about.

3) Story is lackluster.
= The story lacks any form of inspiration or excitement. The story is too straightforward without any suspense or fear. It goes on sequence by sequence without anything memorable happening.

4) Limited Weapons:
= There are only three type of weapons in Syndicate: brass knuckles (which is awesome! Love fighting with these), cane sword and kukris (basically curved daggers). In comparison to Unity which had a lot more variety to offer, the limited structure of weapons in Syndicate is a letdown for sure, especially as a AC game.

5) Limited Outfits and Customizations:
= Apart from specialized skill tree for Jacob and Evie, there really is not a lot to offer when it comes to customizations. The outfits are very limited, and the corresponding color customization is quite boring (color does not pop). I expected more customizations for Syndicate.

6) Jacob and Evie can't walk normally with their hoods up.
= Jacob will wear a tophat and Evie will just leave her hood down in normal walking mode. As you trigger the stealth mode (entering the stealth mode), Jacob and Evie will pull up their hoods to accomodate their stealth movements. Although I love the fact that you can bring the hood up and down, at least give us a option to put the hood up while walking normally. I can't stand following Charles Darwin with my hood up while crouching. It looks off.

7) Buggy fighting system
= The fighting system in Syndicate is actually pretty smooth. Combat flows and executions, while limited, looks realistic and classy. However, some aspect of the fighting system is buggy. Sometimes a prompt does not appear when someone is about to shoot you, and the next thing you know, you're dead (from higher level enemies). Sometimes attacking an enemy deals no damage, and would get countered instead (almost immediately). I'm fine with a challenging fighting system, but when it bugs so much that it ruins the flow of the game, it is definitely frustrating.

There might be something that I missed in this. Sorry Ubisoft, but AC Syndicate is a major letdown for me. Come back better with an AC game in Feudal Japan, with samurais and ninjas. That, would be epic.

I'm going to recommend this game whilst thinking its not actually very good and here's why:

For me this is a game I turn the sound off to and play while listening to podcasts or something else and mindlessly collect crates and grind to get all the items.

If you've played previous AC games it really doesn't change much apart form perhaps the addition of the grappling hook and change of other items. The open world ubi gameplay is actually amongst the most uninspired I can think of.

Additionally the "save the poor enslaved children to prove how much of an amazing person you are" quests pissed me off. both the design of the buildings they are in and the whole motivation of them was really poorly thought through.

I didn't especially like the 'build your own faction /gang' system and thought it was unnecessary and shoehorned into the
For me this is a game I turn the sound off to and play while listening to podcasts or something else and mindlessly collect crates and grind to get all the items.plot.

The world is quite nice looking and designed nicely in lots of places, but the issue is that the architecture is incredibly repetitive and becomes ubiquitous. Whilst one street or courtyard looks nice it also looks the same as the next.

As a Londoner I feel simultaneously at home with the streets but also irritated by the myriad of inaccuracies and ridiculous stereotypes. As well as the fact my native borough apparently has about 30 houses in it. In fact the size generally annoys me.

It's also fairly buggy with respect to getting caught on stuff or difficulty targeting enemies during fights, and personally I sometimes find the climbing controls annoying.

So onto the less negative stuff:

The lighting and weather effects can combine really well, the sight of a foggy gaslit street at night is lovely.

I really liked the detective DLC, felt better than all the investigating stuff in arkham / witcher games.

Jumping between boats, trains and carriages is quite fun.

The grappling hook is a massive time saver and adds to the general silliness of everything.

Story missions are actually not that bad and I liked both the twins acting and their interactions.

Has a pantomime villain with a fantastic moustache.

Verdict:

I don't think this is a good game, its uninspired buggy and repetitive. Despite all this I still enjoy making a big cuppa tea, listening to something more interesting and jumping about the rooftops of victorian London with a grappling hook and revolver in the rain. Get it on a sale if it goes under a tenner as long as you know that what you're getting isn't amazing.

Recommended
87.2 hrs on record
Posted: 15 July, 2019
Syndicate suffered badly from the fallout following Unity. Unfortunately, it really doesn't deserve this, as it is potentially one of the most underrated games in the series.

Set in London in the full swing of the Industrial Revolution, you play as either of the Frye twins. This provides a great way to switch up gameplay from the start, as you can play different styles as you so wish. The writing for these two is excellent, almost like a dark humour sitcom. However, overall the plot of the game is relatively weak when compared to the earlier editions. Some of the famous people you meet are interesting, Winston Churchill during the WW1 memories was a particular favourite of mine, but typically they don't really tend to go anywhere - they just end up as plot filler.

London is beautifully crafted, from the finery of Buckingham Palace and Westminster, rat infested slums, huge factories and mills to the bustling Thames river with steam tugs continually plying their trade. It is a great rendition of the period, and alongside the excellent soundtrack it provides a wonderful gameplay environment.

The combat system has been tweaked and is pretty much spot on. Not suffering from the frame rate issues of the previous game it is given a chance to shine and it works well. The exp-based system returns which I really enjoy, as it gives you the feeling of progression as you can methodically work your way up to taking on harder and more complex tasks.

Make no mistake this IS typical, formulaic, pre re-worked Assassins Creed - But I have enjoyed rather alot.

Possibly the worst Assassins Creed game in the series.

Why? Well, sure, it may have more "features" or better visuals than older games in the series, yet the utter lack of quality in this game is appalling.

Let's start with the story. The story has no build up whatsoever. No character development. No reason to care at all about anything you do. Other games in the series have made distinct attempts to get you attached to the characters you play as, and reasons to feel a need to stop the main villain. This game has none of that. Right from the start, you're thrown in as the Frye twins, with no goal other than to stop a moustache twirling Templar who wants to control the UK. Nothing is known of this villain. Nothing is known of your heroes. You're just thrown into the dull story. The characters do not help with this either. Historical characters are misrepresented, and everyone in the story seems to be a silly do-gooder, or a moustache twirling bond villain.

Now onto actual gameplay. The gameplay feels like a really â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ transition between the RPG mechanics of Origins and Odyssey, and the classic AC mechanics of all the prior games. And it shows. It all feels so abrasive and out of place. Furthermore, the world is choked full of repetitive side quests which you must do to "reclaim london" from the templars. These side quests are not fun, and you'll probably have to repeat them many times. The main quests have a bit more variation, but even then, they don't leave you wanting more.

Finally, the visuals. A notable downgrade from AC Unity, the visuals in this game are very disappointing. Whilst not by any means bad, there is no reason that this game should look worse than Assassins Creed: Unity. I expected it would, if anything, look better.

Overall, a terrible story, horrible characters with no development, horrible character tropes repeated through every person you meet in the game, downgraded visuals, lame RPG mechanics, un-engaging combat, and a lame story. Save your money and skip this game. The only reason that anyone might consider purchasing this would be to be "filled in" on the Assassins Creed story, but a youtube video can do that just as well.

Recommended
102.5 hrs on record
Posted: 23 February, 2018
This is a fantastic open-world game that is a solid addition to the franchise. The highlights for me were the attention to detail in crafting Victorian London, the quests involving famous Victorian era figures, and the high-quality storytelling. The least interesting aspect to me was the meta-plot behind Abstergo and their latest machinations, but thankfully it doesn't get in the way of the story of Evie's and Jacob's conquest of London through subterfuge and (of course) assassination.

The gameplay seems deceptively simple, as I have come to expect in AC games. However, as you progress through the game the gameplay develops and matures well. There have been some interesting things done with vehicle travel, allowing you to hijack carriages and carts a la Grand Theft Auto. There have also been some incredible additions to vertical movement which I really enjoyed. Vertical movement has always been a strong suit of AC games, but in Syndicate they really take it to the next level.

The character customization leaves a little bit to be desired. You aren't really forced to make any choices, you just eventually earn all the special abilities. Thus there really isn't much point to replaying the game, so I haven't. Even once you have maxed out Evie's and Jacob's abilities, it's still fun to dash around London finding new ways to cause mayhem and chaos or look for hidden treasures.

Overall, it was a fantastic experience. There's a lot in here for fans of story-based and open-world play. The pacing was excellent, the voice-acting was well done, and the characters were intriguing. The game even offers a sort of "choose your own level of challenge" by offering lots of optional objectives which really give you nothing more than the satisfaction of having done them (i.e. a little XP which there is more than enough of).

I had a lot of fun playing this game.

Posted: 9 July, 2016
Assassinâs Creed Syndicate
is 2015âs entry to the popular Assassinâs Creed franchise. With claims that the franchise is growing stale and 2014âs Assassinâs Creed Unity, the franchise needs to win its fans back. Does it, though? As a huge fan of the series who detested ACIII and Unity, I think it did.
TL;DR version at the bottom of the review.

STORY: Set in 19th century industrial London, the story follows the twins Jacob and Evie Frye on their quest to take a mega baddie Templar whose name I totally forgot. Does that say enough about the story? Not really. The story of Assassinâs vs. Templars is getting a bit stale by the 9th entry in the series and the game does not offer anything new in that regard. What it does though is throw us right into the action of that conflict without dragging out the first part of the game by giving us how the twins joined the creed or any backstory. I personally found that a bit refreshing.

Jacob and Evieâs personalities and methods are different. He likes to use brute force and go out with style while she likes to plan ahead and do things discreetly and stealthily. Their banter is one of the highlights of the gameâs narrative, I just loved watching the two of them go at it on screen. Their journey to take down the Templars in London makes them cross paths with historical figures such as queen Victoria, Charles Dickens, and Charles Darwin. The two also form a street gang called the Rooks in hopes of battling the Templarsâ gang which controls the city.
The game does nothing to progress the modern day story just like Assassinâs Creed titles since Black Flag.
Overall, the story was nothing groundbreaking yet fun to experience with a slightly disappointing ending.

GAMEPLAY: For the first time in the series, you control two characters that you can be switchable at almost any time. Their differences are stark since Jacob is more of a brute that can sustain a great deal of damage while Evie is better suited for stealth missions. The Assassination missions are a highlight in the game. They are grand in scale with a number of ways to achieve the end goal. I think that they can be compared to Hitman Blood Moneyâs missions though a bit smaller.

Out of all the missions that I played, only one of them was a boring tailing mission! Outside the gameâs main missions, there are a plethora of side missions including the 7 districts to liberate from Templar influence. Each district has 4 different kinds of side missions you need to complete in order to liberate said district with a finale consisting of an epic gang war.

As for the movement, the parkour mechanics improve upon those of Unity and they do a great job at it. Free running has two dedicated buttons now; one takes you up while the other one takes you in the opposite direction. This new system is great, but only when it works. I found myself having to climb all the way down a building and climbing back up just get over a small gap thanks to the lack of a jump feature. Yes, you cannot jump since there isnât a dedicated command to do so. The new rope launcher is a welcome addition to the series and is actually one of my favorite gadgets. It makes traversing the streets of London faster and more fun. Think of yourself as a 19th century Spiderman. Drivable carriages were also a welcome addition since the city is so large (30% larger than Unityâs Paris). I did find one odd thing about climbing, though, it feels as if the player can only move in a grid because sometimes I would try to climb certain objects that were normally climbable in previous AC games but couldnât as Jacob (or Evie) would just skip them and go over them.
Combat is finally fun to play and not only to watch! Much needed improvements were made to the combat which makes it fast, fluid, and most importantly, fun. The brutal combat animations make Jacob and Evie look as badass as they dress.

It is important to note that the game is the first Assassinâs Creed title not to feature any form of multiplayer since Assassinâs Creed Brotherhood. To be honest, I donât really miss it.

GRAPHICS: The game is beautiful to gawk at. The busy streets of London feel alive with carriages, workers, children, merchants and all sorts of people roaming around. Gang wars also come to life with two dozens of NPCs battling it out while you mow them down with great combat animations and executions. Facial animations were also great except the weird and quirky facial animations of gang members. Location wise, London itself is a good location for an Assassinâs Creed title, but I feel that the European locations are growing a bit stale since I feel that they are mostly the same.

AUDIO: Voice acting is superb that, especially Jacob and Evieâs which makes their banter even more enjoyable. Music is atmospheric and fits the game. Other than that it isnât as memorable as ACIIâs or Revelationsâ.

TL;DR:
Pros:
Great characters
Great assassination missions
Fun self-contained story
Fun, exciting combat
Good parkour mechanics
The rope launcher
Beautiful city
Cons:
Disappointing ending
A few weird choices with the parkour system
Forgettable villain
Zero advancements in the modern day story
Overall, Assassinâs Creed Syndicate is a solid new entry in the franchise that is better treated as an individual game since it does nothing to advance the overall Assassinâs Creed story arc. The game features improved combat and parkour and a fun, self-contained story.

8/10

Recommended
136.2 hrs on record
Posted: 20 November, 2015
Brief review after 6 hours: It's great. The Victorian era is one of my favorite historical settings and AC's London does it justice. Even if the story ends up being terrible (it's fine so far, and has a decent amount of humor to boot), the city is magnificent and I'm really impressed with the number of moving parts--boats, carriages, trains, factory machinery, and so forth.

Important note: if you have a graphics card with only 2 GB VRAM (I have a 2 GB Nvidia 960), it might be worth your while to try going over the memory threshold shown on the graphics options screen. When I tried this with GTA V, the game stuttered, but when I try this with AC: Syndicate, the game shrugs and says "Eh, why not." Of course there are limits, but with a little experimentation I was able to get the game to run very smoothly and still show textures that aren't blurry messes (which they are on Low). Maybe Ubisoft sandbagged it a little to avoid a deluge of complaints. Whatever the reason, it's worth fiddling with the settings.

Edit: Additional technical info: playing at 1920x1080, Intel i7-4790K @ 4 GHz.

Updated info after 70 hours: Well, I'm getting close to finishing the story missions and everything I said above still holds. Since I've already said plenty of nice stuff about the game, here I would like to point out a few nitpicks.

Muted outfit colors: The in-game outfit artwork shows vivid reds and dark blacks, but the actual colors you can use with your outfit are toned down. This is the Victorian era, friends, let us get fancy.

Helix credits: I don't mind paying for good DLC, but Helix credits seem like a raw deal, particularly since they only buy things that should be covered by difficulty sliders. It's as though you bought a calculator but had to pay extra to use the trig functions. It wouldn't be so bad if you got a lot of them for a couple bucks, I guess, but these prices are eye-popping and jaw-dropping. So I haven't bought any.

Mission glitch: I found one mission (going slumming, literally, with a wealthy lady) would not complete properly for me--the game would freeze with a perpetual "saving" icon when the mission ended. It turns out you need to get her home before she stops talking. Easy enough to get around once you look up a workaround on the Internet, but it really should work properly.

Typefaces: Overall, the typefaces you'll see on in-game signage are what you'd want and expect, but there are a couple signs in there that were apparently designed in Microsoft Word using whatever font was handy, and whenever I see one it's like finding a 1979 penny in my pocket and being rudely yanked back into modernity.

Still, it's a great game all in all.

Update after 82 hours: There is a really annoying bug on replays of kidnapping and Templar hunting missions: the game may fail the mission immediately after loading it. Then it will reload, and maybe it will work or maybe it will fail again. It seems to load properly eventually, but I've seen it reload 4 or 5 times before working. Annoying. Then again this is the first Assassin's Creed game where I've been motivated to go back and replay missions to complete all the side requirements, so I guess I'll just have to hope they patch it.

Keg
397 products in account
0
7 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
100.6 hrs on record
Posted: 28 November, 2021
Taking place closest in history to us, the game takes place in Victorian England following the Frye twins and their goal of taking back control of London from Templar hands, following the assassination of Edward Kenway years earlier. Having a unique opportunity to play as two different people, switching from one to another in a matter of a second, the game gives us two different perspectives from the same side, one that abides by the Creed and follows in her father's footsteps focusing on the Piece of Eden, and the other swaying away from his sister's goal to take matters into his brawling hands by forming a gang to take down Templar lieutenants, crippling their control. Gang members act in the similar way as Assassin recruits did in some previous games, helping protagonists in a more direct way rather than from the shadows.
The twins give a fresh approach to the otherwise single main charater, each with their own views of the world and how to approach and solve certain problems. Evie is charming, eager to help, while Jacob just as charming is more playful in his approach, not taking himself or the problems around him too seriously, but fully aware they are.

Traversing London's 4 to 5-story buildings is made easier by the new gadget, the rope launcher, making reaching the tops of buildings a breeze, as well as quickly "hopping" from one rooftop to the next. Another new gadget is the introduction of the voltaic bomb which, similar to the smoke bomb, incapacitates enemies but also damages them as well.
A welcome return to the franchise are the whistle and for PC players a mouse wheel as a method for cycling through weapons, both having been removed in Unity, with takedown opportunities continuing in Syndicate. The looting of bodies also gets a boost, having been severely nerfed in Unity, giving more consumables and reducing the need to shop after or during missions.
There are 3 different weapon types to use, kukri, cane-swords & knuckles, offering 3 different styles of combat to pick from, as well as firearms and Assassin gauntlets. There are plenty of styles to acquire, some requiring crafting, each offering different stats, most notably belts for Jacob and capes for Evie offering defense and stealth points, and their various outfits stat boosts. The cost of weapons and outfits is in the realm of affordability, yet another welcome change from Unity, and making money to purchase them comes in the form of pubs' income that needs to be unlocked under gang upgrades, which is then easily picked up from the train's vault, as well as various side missions generously providing another income.

The hideout this time around is a moving train that circles the entire playable London area that can be easily boarded and disembarked at any moment, climbed on top for a more adventurous travelling experience and even sight see from within the train with an option to change camera angles and view London from unique perspectives.

Similar to Unity's helix glitches that take place in different time periods, one of Syndicate's optional memories takes place during World World I, taking place years after the events of the main game, the short story following Jacob's granddaughter Lydia helping Winston Churchill with the enemy threat on home soil.

Syndicate DLCs offer more in term of extra missions, weapons and outfits, one of which brings back murder mysteries from Unity while playfully introducing the creator of one of the most famous detectives in The Dreadful Crimes DLC.
Jack the Ripper DLCs however, gives us an Assassin's Creed's take on the famous serial killer that terrorized Victorian London, by offering a connection between the Assassins and the Ripper. Taking place 20 years after the main story we once again get to play as Evie as she returns to London looking for her brother after his disappearance, but getting to play a few short missions as the Ripper himself as well. His perspective is so unusually different, fitting perfectly with his maniacal persona, and playing as him satisfies that dark parts of ourselves we sometimes like to peer into. The DLC also introduces the fear element into the story and combat, and although fun to use and play around with, it somewhat defeats the purpose of being an Assassin if taking down enemies is not by assassinating them. It's a fun, innovative way of subduing enemies and an ideal tactic that should've only be used by the Ripper himself.

As the last true Assassin's Creed game in the franchise it's nostalgic looking back at how far the franchise has come, accomplishing so much by each new title, expanding on the gameplay mechanics and the connecting story from the very first to this last game. Syndicate is a strong addition to the rest of the titles that by the ending of the Ripper DLC creates a sense of sadness as we say goodbye to a long journey where we followed so many Assassins throughout the game's history that helped shape the world and its future, unsure if we'll ever get to take similar journeys again. Even the modern day part ends in the same vein, leaving us on a cliffhanger not knowing what the future will bring. Regardless of the changes waiting down the line we'll always be able to go back to 9 games that made us all Assassins by the end.

Requiescat in pace.

Not Recommended
39.0 hrs on record
Posted: 28 October, 2020
Excellent world, beautiful art. Horrible controls, bunches of bugs and movement glitches. Terrible game design choices in terms of control schemes, difficulty, mission design, and so on. The only thing that keeps me coming back to finish the story is the world design. I do feel quite immersed into late 19th century London, so they nailed that. I just cannot stand failing a mission because my character jumped in the complete wrong direction, or dropped someone in front of a carriage instead of putting them inside one, or many of the other errors that could have easily been avoided in a better designed game.

AI behavior is extremely inconsistent. You can murder someone right in front of them and they won't ever see you. Other times you can fling a knife from a rooftop 20 meters away and they'll immediately initiate combat and bring the whole gang with them. Your own gang ally members can sometimes run into an area while you're sneaking around doing your assassin things, and initiate combat with enemies, sometimes causing you to fail optional objectives, or causing kidnap targets to run away. There is no way to tell your allies to stay away. You only get to watch as your targets are meddled with by a stupid AI.

Combat is extremely frustrating. You can attack lightning fast about 4 times in a row, and then suddenly your character refuses to move for a good 2 seconds to leave an opening for the enemy to hit back. If you're fighting a group of enemies, it will throw 3 different button queues at you at a time. You can not do anything in this situation because if you press 1, you miss the other 2 and take damage and most likely stagger as well, where another couple enemies might attack you again. Enemies have the ability to block, which requires a heavy attack to break their defense. If you hit them with a light attack, they will stagger you and hit you back. That's fine and fair, however it takes a million years to pull off a heavy attack, during which you can be attacked by other enemies. Also, enemies can start to block while you're in the middle of attacking them, so they get a cheap deflect since there's no way to cancel your attacks. There really should have been a dodge/roll button that can be used at any time in combat. During combat, your camera is locked down below a certain angle. If there is a sniper above the fight, you are simply NOT ALLOWED to look up at them to do something about it. Despite, you know, the main gimmick of this game being a GRAPPLE HOOK, and the fact that you have a gun for just such a thing. Speaking of which, you are completely unable to manually aim your gun during combat. The aim button isn't even used for anything else in combat!!! Why the hell can't you still aim if you want to???

Also, speaking of the grapple, it does make traversal much nicer than having to climb up and down repetitively. It's a little clunky, but it can be forgiven because you're not supposed to be Spiderman, you're supposed to be a 19th century assassin. The major problem with it is you cannot aim where you want to fire the grapple. You have to completely rely on the contextual auto-aim by looking around. I cannot tell you how many times I've looked straight forward at a roof in front of me, but Jacob or Evie TURN AROUND and grapple up onto the building behind me. That wouldn't have happened if I was allowed to manually aim to which ledge I wanted to go to.

I really wanted to like this game. Somewhere within, there is a really good game. It's just buried under the layers of terrible, contextual controls and shoddy AI. I am really hoping Origins improves upon these things.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate is quite simply the most disappointing Assassins Creed game in the series, and for quite a few reasons. While the visuals are good and the setting within a huge industrious city is impressive, this game falls short in every other way of any previous game. Graphics and controls are better in unity. Story is better in literally any previous game. Weapons and combat are better in all the other games. Vehicles are terrible. Skills and levels are pointless and the gang system is incredibly expensive. This game feels more like a 'Beat 'em up' than an Assassins Creed game, and it is by far the biggest let down.
The Story is terrible - if there even was a story. You play as Jacob and Evie Frye, as they embark on a mission to track down a Precursor Artifact and free London from the Templars. That's it. For 18 hours. You accomplish this by playing many side missions and going on as many wild goose chases as possible, making gameplay incredibly boring. The area takeover missions are dull and repetitive, and in the end pointless. In the end the two characters run off into the distance and it feels like you haven't actually experienced a story at all... was the whole story just a prologue? Sure felt like it. And the Characters have no development at all. Jacob stays a brash, thoughtless kid who runs around doing whatever he wants, and just feels empty, while Evie is always the caring one but never learns to take action sometimes.
Graphics are nice, but honestly feel like a downgrade from Unity. While London is much larger and far more dense, the cost of losing these visuals just don't seem worth it.
Gameplay has been massively simplified to the point where the game baby-feeds you all sorts of new gadgets and skills that you'll never end up using. The points-based skill system is interesting as it actually lets you develop as a player, but can be annoying if you just want to level up but placed the wrong points in another area. Combat is the worst it has ever been. Sure it changed in Unity, but this is ridiculous. The game has become more of a 'Punching Sim', where I can stab someone 6 times and they still somehow have enough willpower and blood to counter and and defend themselves? Yeah sure, thanks Ubisoft.
Overall, Assassins Creed Syndicate feels like its supposed to be a different game, with completely new combat and a bizarre story that feels like it was mangled just to fit the Assassins Creed overall story. The one good part of this game is the grapple. My god, it made the whole game at least enjoyable for climbing. To bad they downgraded the parcour system they perfected in Unity to make climbing buildings without the grapple pure pain.
Assassin's Creed Syndicate gets a 2/10.

For more reviews check my Steam profile
Hope you enjoyed my review, god bless you
