Pros:
-Being able to have your own gang and give them upgrades
-New tech like trains and revolvers
-Carriges are a fun way to get around
-Open world is very interesting
-It runs better than Unity
-you can switch characters
-interesting side activities
Cons:
-The story and narrative is lackluster, it is not as strong as the older titles. When I first finished this game in May 2016 (the pros of this review are pretty much the same as when I first wrote it in November 2015, it is the cons that have changed), I liked the story, but editing this review in 2020, I gave it way more credit than it deserved. It was corny, that goes for all the main characters, as they all represent simple personalities for most of the game, and just as It is superficially Assassin's Creed, because while the story has all the traditional elements, a big bad Templar and his goons you need to assassinate, with a piece of Eden macguffin involved, the story lacks heart and soul, it does not give you enough reason to care or be invested until , which is not good enough because the story beforehand did not develop up to there properly. This game had the potential for a great narrative and cast of characters, they could have done it if they just took longer. If they want to learn how to write enjoyable stories, they need only look to the Ezio Trilogy of Assassin's Creed Games.

Another problem is while the open world is overall good, it can feel dead in places. The London Stories, where you do side missions for famous historical figures who were in London at the time, were great. The gang-activities however, have their fun parts, but since most of them are just copies of each other, with only the kidnapping missions have unique dialogue, they get stale fast. There are far less buildings you can go inside than the previous game, Assassin's Creed Unity. There are plenty of skyscrapers in the City of London, barrack-like apartments for factory workers in Southwark, and upscale penthouses in Westminster, and they look like such a natural and realistic part of the Victorian open world, but you cannot go into them, interact with them, or get a quest from people inside them, or as I should say, the overwhelming majority of them, I would say ninety percent, and this kills the immersion.

This game had a great and mostly enjoyable open world with plenty of fun things to do, but heavily fell short when it comes to an enjoyable narrative and world depth. It was good but not great. Final verdict: 7/10

This must sound crazy, but I got into Syndicate after playing a fair bit of Odyssey and Origins. I've had my fun with huge open-world maps brimming with quests, but Assassin's Creed was never meant to be that game.

LONDON is just glorious and comes alive in a lot of ways. I'm still marveled by the trains that never stop running. And that you can plop yourself on top of one and get a jolly ride with a view. Fortunately, I experienced zero bugs. The graphics were a hoot with some really beautiful lighting at dawn and dusk. And I keep thinking, why do I need an entire map of Greece when I can have ONE well laid-out city with a lot of hidden surprises and monuments to explore.

AC:Syndicate really harkens back to what I call the controlled independence. You still can go everywhere and start certain quests at random, but there's no way to "fail" a quest. The Animus kicks you out and puts you back to the last checkpoint. There are no choices to make, only a illusion of them. Well you can choose how you want to approach an assassination, but that's about it.

At this point, the present-day story is pretty much a dud and is just there because I think Ubisoft doesn't think it can throw it away entirely. What started out as a nice framing device with Desmond is now in a rubble. I was hoping something interesting might happen at the end but to no avail. All in all, get it if you really miss the Assassin's Creed of yore.

P.S. I can't be the only one to hate naval combat, so I didn't miss that at all here!!

31.3 hrs on record
Posted: 19 November, 2015
It appears to be one of the smaller Assassin's Creed games. Yes, London is big, but that's it really. 6 hours in, and I've conquered 1/4th of London, and am just starting on the last row of skills.

The grappling is great.

Combat is fine.

Evie and Jacob have almost the exact same skill trees, except for 3 skills each the other doesn't. I've basically built the two the exact same.

The interplay between the two is great, even if it's very much a caricature (Jacob is the simple man, Evie is the more thoughtful woman, etc). As the two are essentially the same in terms of play, I just play Evie except for the occaisional mission in which you have to use Jacob.

This is the first Assassin's Creed that injects some humor throughout. It's a nice touch, and a nice break from the traditional seriousness of the franchise.

I hate the train. :D It's so damn slow. Get those fast travel points as soon as you can.

Difficulty wise, this is probably the easiest AC yet, though that seems to partly be due to overleveling, and even a level's difference in a fight has a large effect.

My gang is overleveled too, I guess. I don't really use them unless the story throws them into the fray on its own, and in those moments, my gang basically kills everything in a matter of seconds. :/

Overall, I'm enjoying it. Largely in part to the two main characters; I just enjoy the two of them. Haven't really enjoyed the main character in an AC game since the (younger) Ezio days. We've had some gawd awful AC protagonists since then (bottoming out with Connor). Jacob and Evie are a refreshing change.

Only had one crash. Was transitioning from the map back to the game, and it just froze in an all white screen. The only weird issue I encountered was when I was in a kidnap mission, everytime I restrained my victim, an invisible wall would spring up, preventing me from walking forward (and, in fact, would push me backwards). I got around that by facing in the opposite direction I wanted to walk, waited for the victim to try to break free, restrained victim, and then turned around and walked. It's only occurred the one time in a kidnapping mission. All the others I've done had no issues.

Overall technical side of the port seems great.

Parkor controls are just as good (and bad) as always.

At this point in the game, I'd give it a 9/10. They haven't really done much to change the AC formula, but after a long string of ACs that I didn't particularly enjoy (from a characters/story perspective), this has been a fun ride so far. It might be coloring my opinion a bit, and it's quite possible that once this initial euphoria of actually enjoying an AC story/characters again fades, I'd really be around an 8/10.

Another assassin's creed game..

After waiting for more than a month to play this game on PC and after reading many reviews on PS4 I am finally able to see all the glory for myself.

Yes, GLORY. You read that right.

I too was expecting another â¥â¥â¥â¥ show, the return of Unity's game breaking bugs and boring gameplay, retarded AI and dry story.

But this is not the case with Syndicate. Syndicate combines the good looking graphics and enormous city of Unity and the attention to detail and interesting game mechanics of Black Flag.

We see the return of the Whistle, we can also carry bodies and hide them or put them in a particular spot to attract attention. Combat has been refreshed and while at the first few levels its a little bit boring, it gets much more interesting later on as you aquire new skills and combos.

The game offers a variety of activities stretching from Fight Clubs, Carriage races to Templar Hunts and Gang Wars.

The story 6 hours into the game appears to be much more immersive and connected to the Real Life stuff - something that was missing in Unity.

There are no game breaking bugs in the game but it is far from perfect optimisation. London's streets sees less people than Paris and this has helped bring down the load on your CPU, however all the Nvidia Gameworks gizmos sure take a load on your GPU. With my GTX 970 i can have almost everything maxed out and i manage to keep it just over 55 fps.

Overall the game plays really well and it offers long hours of gameplay.

Worth the 59$!

Recommended
33.4 hrs on record
Posted: 11 April, 2016
TL;DR Damn close to 10/10, possibly my new favorite in the AC series

I was very critical of Unity. The story was unfocused, Arno had very little character development and just felt like an Ezio copy. The gameplay was changed for the worse, I only remember 3 characters (including the main playable) and it was too crowded.

Syndicate feels like a true AC game, better than the Ezio trilogy. The best part is having two characters makes for more to go off of for them. Jacob is a fighter & takes the most action, but his weakness is that he causes the most chaos. Evie is the stealth character that is much smarter & applies critical thinking to situations, but at times doesn't take enough action to help out. Having the character flaws isn't bad, they both make up for it with a yin/yang mix as twins.

The villains this time are FAR more memorable. Each character got so much more development and much better blue screen deaths than in the past. Having each character's role outlined (ie: the banker, the scientist, the doctor, the transporter, etc) makes their missions, motives, character traits far more memorable.

The actual assassination missions were the best. Not since AC1 have I looked forward to actual Templar assassinations, but that was because AC1 had â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ gameplay elsewhere other than the assassinations.

The music is incredible, by far the best since AC2 & Brotherhood's soundtrack but actually I'd say even better.

Here are my complaints:

-At the beginning, the Mentor named George lectures the twins about staying away from London. They disobey him and he's never heard from again. I was expecting him to show up in sequence 4 or 5 with his monacle broken & jowels flapping. I was disappointed.

-The main villain, Crawford Starrick, is a really good presence & very well acted. However, literally every scene but the final sequence has him in his office assigning other people to do dirty work. He never does any actual fieldwork or has any interaction with them face to face. Granted, you can say "Well, London was completely under his control so he didn't need to leave his office", but tha'ts weak.

-The sidequests have very little payoff. I only did them for fun. Hell, I cleared out a huge chunk of chests & collectibles for fun, but that was just me enjoying the game. There really is no actual payoff to it unless if I was achievement hunting, which I'm not on Ubiplay garbage.

Anyway, great game, worth the $20 I spent it on. Hope the one in 2017 is even better.

Not Recommended
75.0 hrs on record
Posted: 29 June, 2020
Game freezes every 2 or 5 mins for 4 -7 secs randomly. I tried almost every fix.

*********************
// Edit:

Specs:

Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-7700HQ CPU @ 2.80GHz

NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060

RAM: 16339 Mb

___________________________________________________

I got it to work. All I have to do is open the Nvidia Control Panel, add this in the program settings tab, set power management to Adaptive, limit the max frame rate to 30 FPS, open task manager, set ACS.exe's priority to Normal, set the affinity and uncheck CPU 0. Go to the in-game options, turn Vsync off, set the refresh rate to 60hz, set the environment to Very High, set textures to Medium,, set shadow quality to High, ambient occlusion to SSAO, and anti aliasing to FXAA.

Game looks passable and the frame rate takes a little getting used to but at least its playable.

I didn't know any of that bollocks settings 3 days ago. I'm just a filthy casual. Glad I learned something new. Thanks Ubisoft.

I still wouldn't recommend this game though. My solution might not work for you.

The lead characters Jacob and Evie are diverse and their constant differences and arguments pretty much sums up for strong character development in this one. The game is very polished and the bugs are ironed out. The combat is well balanced, the open world is fun,the sandbox approach is way more polished and transportation is a lot improved(horse carriages, the most awesome AC2 set piece now implemented in the open world) and rope launcher is a time saver and it also doesn't restrict you to enjoy the old building climbing. During story missions, however, you're usually locked into one character and will switch only when the game wants you to. Wow...I think I'm in love, with the series, again. Yeah, I thought those were the best 3, but I still like the rest of the franchise as well. Even Unity, which I got well after all the dust had settled and was able to play pretty much trouble-free except for some minor inconsequential issues.

Syndicate makes me love the series again, though, like I did back when the best ones came out. This game...

I've played every mainline AC game until now. After ACIII, I became completely desinterested in this series, yet I somehow continued playing it. Well, for the first few hours, it isn't. It's quite competent. It looks really nice, runs well, if you have the PC that can run it, plays a bit better than the games before it in the series. But then you get into the completely pointless story, that doesn't engage you in any way. Cardboard cutouts of characters interacting with each other to no point. A shoehorned love plot, that has not earned its right to be in the game (suddenly one main character has feelings for another guy... but we're not shown why or how it happened. It just happens).

The main story arc can be explained in maybe two minutes. The rest is filler. There's no twists, no turns. Just "kill that guy" and find the MacGuffin. Nothing else... but it's stretched to a good 10 to 20 hours (if you focus on the story).

The last two or three memories are THE worst, though. Suddenly, you get contacted by some guy... that sort of wants to play a game with you and your enemies. It's 4 missions, or so, of complete filler, with mission designs directly lifted from the open world â¥â¥â¥â¥ you're tasked to do to free London anyways. And in the end, he "betrays you" and you kill him. Completely out of the blue. No real connection to the rest of the game. Seems like it was supposed to be DLC, but it wasn't good enough to sell on its own, so it was boxed with the game.

And climax makes you play f*cking GTA taxi missions, for gods sake. And for what? Some irrelevanat dialogue of a guy you only met once before and you'll never meet again, about stuff that doesn't matter in the game at all. Only for him to give you some plans.

Some missions forbid you to do the stuff you do all the time... like kill people. Why? Doesn't tell you... in some missions, it doesn't even tell you that, beforehand. You just fail, if you kill... only then you know. Some "additional mission incentives" make you not kill Templars. That goes against what the Assassins do. WHY would a 100% sync make me NOT kill them? No reason given. This doesn't happen often, but it stands out.

I was actually getting angry at the game in the end. It was such lazy mission design. None of it stood out. The story, the missions, everything was lazily thrown together to meet the deadline of christmas. Given, it works a lot better than Unity did on release... but I think Unity was, at least to some degree, a better game with a more engaging story (and that says a lot, since I didn't like Unity that much, either)

The endboss is... boring... I'll leave it there.

So... in the end, save you some money. Rather get Black Flag, Brotherhood or AC2. All of those games are miles better than Syndicate, run better on older hardware, and have much better mission design. Though some flaws noted here are present in those games as well.

Even worse is the fact that you simply cannot jump from a building if the game deduces that you will get hurt â self-determination be damned, youâre flat-out denied the ability to leave the top of a building by any means other than scaling it or leaping into a haystack. The developers have endeavoured to stop the player leaping blind to their death, and have unfortunately stopped the player leaping at all.

This is perhaps the most annoying side-effect of the changes, although I also found the target tracker to be very touchy - performing multiple takedowns almost entirely boils down to whether the game decides that it wants to let you do it, and while double assassinations used to be easy to execute as long as the enemies were within a few feet of one another, it now seems that you need to approach from a very specific angle regardless of how close the enemies are to one another, and even a change of a few degrees will sour your plans and alert the one enemy you failed to attack.

The physics system can be quite janky, and corpses flop and bend in strange and unnatural ways. I also had a number of fatal, unexplained crashes that brought me back to the desktop - an annoying occurrence given that UPlay is so slow that both shutdown and startup can take minutes at a time.

Syndicate is not the saviour of the series, is what Iâm saying...but that doesnât make it a bad game. I have a tendency to rant about annoyances while glossing over major boons, and aside from the stunning presentation of the city, there is some sense of levity added to the formula in the numerous entertaining money-earning activities. These particularly come into their own after meeting and completing the first mission of the character of Ned Wynert â you can rob trains, hijack carts of enemy provisions, defend your own carts that tour the city, and rob or sabotage enemy ships that sail down the Thames.

On top of that, each borough of London lies in the hands of the enemy gang. Their hold can be loosened by performing a number of missions such as Templar assassinations, freeing child labourers, and kidnapping gang leaders and delivering them to the constabulary. For each of these actions completed, a section of the borough comes under your control, and is populated with your gang members. They didnât make the same mistake as Far Cry 3 and 4 and turn your territories into a ghost town upon liberation, and enemies still appear with a reduced frequency, but now you will have more help at hand should you stumble across an interloper within your territory.

However, while not anywhere near as fraught as Unity, Syndicate retains the signs that the formula is simply exhausted and stagnant, and while I can enjoy the virtual tourism in any way shape or form, thereâs something irrepressibly tedious about having to go through the motions of another âAssassinâs Creedâ game. Syndicate is a more enjoyable experience than ACIII, and certainly an improvement on Unity, but for those looking for the quintessential AC experience, youâll likely find it elsewhere.

However, I am annoyed at Ubisoft for removing the "free jump" feature, which was present in essentially every single previous title. Being forced to jump down from buildings/obtacles, or just jumping off a ledge/bridge is a serious pain in the ass. Completely negates fluidity, which I believe to be the sole purpose of introducing the jump up/down feature. Ubisoft has to know that this feature is quite good, but it is supposed to complement free jumping, not replacing it. Thus, I think this game is a step down from AC Unity's parkour system.

Story and character wise, everything is quite predictable. The story is a tad bland at times, and we weren't given an in-depth story of the characters so it's hard to be attached to them. However, I do enjoy the fact that they're assassins right from the start, unlike other games where you're forced to play their pre-assassins life.

There isn't much else to say really, but I do recommend this game, especially if you're a true AC fan. I have every game in the series thus far, aside from the 2D side scroller ones, and Syndicate is a game I've definitely enjoyed despite having so many new features that I'm not used to.

Not Recommended
74.3 hrs on record
Posted: 1 March, 2019
Edit: played it another time only to find the story more boring, and the crime DLC lost a lot of charm in second playthrough. However! If you go directly to the west side districts after getting the rope launcher, this game can be a somewhat fun ninja game.
"ITS LIKE SEKIRO WITH OP WHISTLE"
It's similar to overlevelled fort raid in Odessey and Origin, but you can actually assassinate stuff reliably. Some of the races are still incredibly annoying though.

Much less glitchy than Unity, but still somehow a disappointment due to copy-pasted blocks and unimpressive story. If you like detective story, then you can buy the game with the Dreadful Crime DLC (not included in the Syndicate-Rogue-Unity bundle). If you like Saints Row you probably will have some fun, but the side activities are much more boring than the wacky and over-the-top SR missions. If you just want Victorian steampunk games, I recommend Bioshock Infinite and Dishonored (both are first person though).

Pro of this game:
-Less glitchy than Unity. The game also has a main menu (Yes, since we have the bizarre visual torture tool called AC Unity, these are actually "strength" of a game).
-Industrial age London is beautiful, especially for steampunk lovers. This is the only AC game where you own a train. Also there are ships and factories.
-Some of the BGMs are good.
-Rope launcher. This is the coolest thing in AC universe and allows you to roam around like a ninja.
-Carriages are overall fun.

Cons of the game, and why I rank this among the worst AC games:
-The illusion of content. This is a problem of Ubisoft Quebec games, such as Odessey and Syndicate. They have ridiculously beautiful areas (Laconia and Korinthia in Odessey, Westminster in Syndicate) that urge you to yell "Best game EVER!" However, then you realize that they only contribute to a tiny part of the gameplay. You are going to spend most of your time playing in the repetitive copy-pasted maps (forts and leader houses in Odessey and blocks and factories in Syndicate). Even the rope launcher ninja part cannot save the stale gameplay.
-Train robbery and ship robbery are so underwhelming that it's not funny.
-I'm okay with less weapon types (AC2 doesn't have much weapon choices either), but the combat feels repetitive. You don't feel you deliver enough punch, especially if you use cane-sword which is the only cool weapon.
-The main story, side stories and two story DLCs are incredibly weak. The game has no beginning; it seems that you are defying the will of council and travel to London, but the council never show up again. It's like starting the game in the middle of AC Brotherhood with an intro: "you are playing as Ezio Auditore, and your mission is to assassinate the super duper bad Cesare Borgia, now go play! Don't forget to give us a 10/10 rating!" (Just in case you don't know, AC Brotherhood is the middle game in Ezio Auditore trilogy.)
-The final boss is slightly better than unity, but the fight is very disappointing. Your sidekick, Henry Green, is underdeveloped as well despite the fact that he becomes very important to your character. I get that Ubisoft cannot point real historical figures as the main antagonist, because they will get sued by heirs of the historical individual. But the boss suffers a lot from his weak background.
-Your characters are bland and show little growth. We no longer have the morally grey settings that add more depth to Kenway series and Unity. Instead we get a superhero story in which the protagonist constantly mock the victims.
-Personally I think Unity and Syndicate would benefit a lot if the relationship of the protagonists are reversed. In Unity the story makes more sense if Elise is your sister, so that you are not a big part of her path. In Syndicate the characters will have more development if Evie is your lover and the one introducing you to the brotherhood (the AC4 route).

TL;DR: Only buy it on discount, just for the Victorian setting. Otherwise I cannot say it's worth buying, considering that AC4 is just cheaper and better. (If you are really into AC universe you really should spend time playing Ezio trilogy though)

**New Review**

Now that I have sunk more time into it, and gotten past the introduction, I can assuredly say this game is amazing. Combat is challenging yet satisfying. No longer the insane kill count you could get with III, Black Flag, or even Unity some times. Now you have to be cautious with who you pick your fights with.

Rope launcher is one of the funnest tools I've every used in a game. I feel like a mid century Spider-Man swinging around London, and yet, its inclusion doesn't break the gameplay, or negate the free running aspect. Speaking of which, is far more fluid than before. You still get parts where you jump to somewhere you did not want to, but no where near the clunkiness of Unity. The have ironed out the bugs, and given it a more fluid feel, and it is a huge improvement.

Characters are engaging. I have only played with Jacob so far, but the quips he makes as you play throughout the game always seem to make me chuckle. Evie is alright, but I need mroe time playing with her to really flesh out her character. Jacob being more reckless and aggressive, Evie being the voice of reason, and tactical.

Gang wars are enjoyable, and feel great with combat system, and recruiting rooks, and fighting blighters is easily one of my favorite parts of this.

Of course, no doubt everyone is curious about the performance, especially with the debacle of Unity. The game performs flawlessly in that aspect. I have a
GTX 980 and factory clock
Intel i5-4690k at stock clock
16GB of RAM

And it runs the game so, SO smoothly. Im getting a MINIMUM of 60fps, and easily go upwards into 85-90 in the less intensive parts of roaming. No glitches yet, no horryfiying faces, and though they may be there, I have yet to see them.

All in all, this is a great addition to the franchise, and adds several new gameplay elements without being to over the top. 60$ may be a little much for the game, since it is essentially the same formula, but if you enjoy the franchise this is worth picking up.

Alright, now, that I've managed to be almost done with the game, let's talk about what I've experieced with it so far:

Fourth, the level grinding. Just go find a fight club around levels 5-8, keep winning it, and you'll reach level 10 in no time. I actually reached level 10 before sequence 4, complete with the necessary equipments.

For now, this is all I can say about the game. And I sincerely did not regret buying it.

SpiderGoblin
221 products in account
0
6 people found this review helpful
1 person found this review funny 0

Recommended
68.0 hrs on record
Posted: 30 June, 2018
An amazing return to the series after the disaster that was Assassin's Creed Unity. Continues many new concepts introduced in the prior game and improves upon them significantly. My problems with Syndicate are few and far between.

The good:
-Large but not overwhelming map with your typical Ubisoft collectibles. Conquering boroughs for your gang includes varied missions and is plenty of fun.
-Much better skill tree than Unity.
-Fantastic story.
-Interesting characters, especially the twins themselves.
-Much better combat than Unity. One of the few things I liked about Unity was that it tried to reinvent the combat, but it floundered. Syndicate does a much better job.
-Fighting with your gang is very reminiscent of fighting alongside assassins in the Ezio trilogy.
-A really good villain, especially considering how little you really see of him. Much of his character is built up by those beneath him, making the final confrontation all the more intense.
-Handles the present day story the best of the series to date. Everything you see that is happening present day is shown to you in cutscenes after a few sequences of the main story. No time wasting by making you walk around as a present day person, and doesn't completely neglect the story like Unity did.

The bad:
-While I enjoy the differences between Jacob and Evie, the former being adept at combat with the latter adept at stealth, the game is not really presented in a way that capitalizes on their strengths. About 70% of the main story sequences are exclusively played by Jacob, and many of them are stealth-heavy segments. Meanwhile hardly any of Evie's story missions are stealth-heavy. It just seems bizarre to me that the game would fail to put the characters in situations that fit them.
-The twins earn skill points that they invest into skill trees, but aside from 3 unique skills each (combat oriented for Jacob and stealth oriented for Evie), the trees are identical. The game would have much benefitted from the two trees being unique or at least including more unique skills.
-The game introduces a new piece of equipment, the grappling hook, which allows you to scale any building in seconds. This completely eliminates the climbing segments of the game, so despite there being many iconic landmarks to see in London, there are no segments spent on climbing them as seen with previous titles. Some of my favorite parts in the series are when you slowly work your way up a massive landmark, and that is sadly absent in this game.
-The weapons are quite limited, as you're only given the choice between three: the kukri, cane-sword, or brass knuckles.

Overall, there is certainly room for improvements to be made to the RPG systems being introduced into the series, but that is ultimately the main issue I have with this game. Aside from that, it is a fantastic game that has me excited to try the next one.

Not Recommended
62.9 hrs on record
Posted: 27 November, 2017
So I played the entire game start to finish PLUS the DLC. In short, I don't recommend it. Why? I 100% complete the game and it is so repetitive that, you're already tired of the franchise recyling stuff then you see this game take it to the next level.

The Pros: Game runs perfectly fine. The stealth mechanic was vastly improved from the absolute crap that was in Unity where ever enemy had SOP (from MGS4) where they could react based on another teammates response (just like 5 paths of pain). Everyone in Unity was high on 500mg of Caffiene. The moment you threw something or ran from side to side they'd instantly be alerted and the SOP system would kick in and EVREYONE in the entire area would know exactly where you were, no questions asked. Thankfully thats been fixed and made the stealth in this game less annoying.

The Cons: Man... seroiusly... When they were making and play testing this game.. Didn't they ever say, "Hmm... this is so boring and complete trash!"???? The story here is explained in the first 30 mins of the game. London is heavily occupied by Templar control, Jacob and Evie want to fix it. Jacob focuses on killing targets - just like any AC game. While Evie focuses on ONE piece of eden and fixes Jacob's mistakes. Thats it. The villian was by far the weakest in any AC game. He was so tired of this franchise and the game itself that he didn't do anything throughout the ENTIRE GAME. So the story, and main villian were absolute garbage but what about the rest? Well... Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, right? That's all it is. You'll be going around London doing the same crap for the entirety of the game. In the main game you're either doing fight clubs which consists of the same thing multiple times to gain someones loyalty to maximum, or you're kidnapping gang members and handing them over to the cops, or you're stealing carriages carrying supplies, or you're stealing â¥â¥â¥â¥ off boats, or you're freeing children from cleaning the floors, or you're going into gang strongholds and just killing the leader/enemies. Thats it. You'll be doing this MULTIPLE times. I don't know why they don't get a small like maybe 10 man team and have them develop different, distinct side missions. It can't be that hard. To make matters worse the combat is by far the worst and least enjoyable in any AC game. Sure, some of the kill animations can look cool but other than that its just button mashing. I used the mouse+Keybaord for this entire game and it was all about clicking away. Here's how you become a pro at the combat in this game. JUST STARE AT THE ENEMIES HEALTH BAR. When its red, keep clicking, when its yellow, quickly press E, when its grey, hit space bar. thats it. you've mastered it if you can respond to different colors. The DLC does add new combat mechanic called Fear. Which is cool cuz it was in the main game but to a lesser degree (if you killed someone via execution, sometimes enemies would run away in fear). The DLC was heavily based on fear and added 2 new weapons which make no real sense but whatever. As for the side missions in the DLC Jack the Ripper, they were also repetitive. You're either saving a prostitute from a carraige, or you're stopping a guy hurting a woman then shaming him through the alley without being detected (very annoying btw), or your escorting a carriage WHILE DRIVING IT REALLY SLOW + no crashing to a destination point, or you're tailing someone then scaring them, or you're going into a fight club and just beating everyone up like before (or you can scare them all away). Yes there are new thigns added but they are new things that must be done multiple times which makes it become really old and stupid so fast. You literally don't have to think much in this game. Just follow the map. That's all it is. Also there are side objectives during missions like "don't get detected" which is good and can add challenege however; i found myself constantly having to replay some missions because I didn't realize that I wasn't supposed to kill anyone or not go below 30m. The game doesn't warn you about a new side objective coming up within a mission until you're already into it. Which can be irrititating since the game is already really annoying to play.

Lets talk about the Presentation of the game. There is some serious issues here. Firstly i must recommend you play with SweetFX profile. Why? because the game is a soft mess even without any AA. I downloaded some SweetFX profile and changed the vignette to as low as possible and upped the sharpness to 2.00 because the games overall presentation is really soft. If you enable any kind of AA in the game, the image only gets softer. Why? because Ubisoft for some reason thought it would be a good idea to have FXAA or FXAA + MSAA/TXAA which makes the screen look like you put vaseline all over it. Secondly, I was recently playing witcher 3 @1080p with no AA and the game looked absolutely fine. However the amount of shimmering and jaggies in this game are RIDICULOUS. Theres so much of it that i just don't understand how this can be.... Next, the enemies. Seriously... They ALL LOOK THE SAME. weather they are your allies, your targets, or just random people. THEY ARE ALL THE SAME. You'll have a Rook on your team that'll look exactly the same as the Blighter you're supposed to kidnap. Extreme laziness at its best. Sure, other games have had this same issue. But in AC Syndicate, when your main target looks exactly like the last one, it shows. IT REALLY SHOWS. If this was a 3DS game I wouldn't care as much. In AC1 every target had a different face. In this game only select targets have different faces. I don't know man this game could have been really good but if I have to point my finger at ONE thing that could have caused this game to be so crap, it would be that its annualized. A game like this should come out once ever 2-3 years so ideas are refreshed and not recycled. And thats a fact. This game shows that. AC4 was amazing. Completely different and fun. Sure not everyone liked sailing, but you have to give credit where credit is due and that game brought new ideas changing things up a bit. This game however; just tries to recycle some of the good from the past games just to make a game. Thats it. There is a new thing added to this game and thats the Rope Launcher. At first I thought it was pretty cool but then some great immersion breaking things pop up. I wouldn't have minded if the Rope Launcher was used to scale up and down buildings quickly, however; you can clearly see that you're firing an infinite number of ropes, sliding across them, then leaving them. and doing the same thing over and over. That to me is very immersion breaking. and I know why the rope launcher is in the game. Because of the way London is. To get from rooftop on one side of the street to the other is nearly impossible because of the gaps. I wish this game wasn't made in London because of that. It is so annoying chasing targets on the street or on the rooftops. Extremely annoying era. I think it could have been much better in China, or India where homes are compact and close together. Aside from that the last thing that I didn't like was the way the Jack the Ripper DLC was presented. It's shown through the Animus..... You play as 3 different characters... How? Once you play it you'll understand what I mean. But immersion breaking things are present there too.

Overall; game ran fine but is extremely repetitive. Story is nearly absent in the main campaign and the Jack the Ripper DLC has slightly better story but thats about it. Side objectives lacked any kind of creativity. London could have been better explored and utilized but I feel like they missed a good opportunity. I bought this on sale and if you're a fan of Assassin's Creed, I suggest you buy it on sale too if you have to play it. It's probably my least liked Assassin's Creed game. Please play this game with a SweetFX profile to make the game look better.

~Edit~

Since quite a few people actually took a look at my review I feel like I should explain a bit more as to what I stated above.

-Regarding the backstory for the characters, it just felt very rushed compared to other AC games. You jump right into the action with both characters, and with previous AC games, it was not like that whatsoever. Some people might've liked this fast pace change, and I'm sure (maybe) that you learned a bit more about the characters throughout the game, but in my -short- time of playing, I only got a taste of there witty banter towards each other and others.

-I should also throw in, whilst it does say that the two characters have preferred roles (one a brawler and the other more stealth oriented), I didn't feel that difference at all.

-On weapons and equipment, it makes complete sense (excluding the obvious assassin equipment) for the time period. Ubisoft did a good job with that. It's just that the combat with the weapons given to us were just unimpressive, again, compared to the previous AC games. I'm an assassin with access to a vast amount of weapons, so why are my only options a khukri, a cane sword, and some gauntlets? The additions of having a pistol wasn't that bad, however.

-There was a severe lacking of outfits that you could obtain (comparing it from the last game), but I guess something to keep in mind is that you're also playing with two characters. Managing both of the characters loadouts just became ennoying. Now, you can purchase some more outfits as a DLC... :l

-I think the fact that Ubisoft has a feature to buy IG money (I don't know if this has changed) is a bit poor, considering that this is a singleplayer game.

Do I recommend this game at full price? No. Do I recommend it if it ever goes on sale? Yes.

Because whilst I do address some issues about this game, Ubisoft really tried and suceeded to give us a better game from AC Unity. It still feels like an AC game. The combat is still fun. (it however felt better in Unity, refer to my statement about weapons). It still has -some- interesting story to get invested in. It's an alright game. I'd like to say I interested to see what Ubisoft has in store for us for the franchise in the future, but I'd rather much prefer that they take there time on the next one. Recommended
33.9 hrs on record
Posted: 21 May, 2017
8/10 - Very Good

Assassin's Creed: Syndicate is fun to play, with a good main story (as always), lots of side missions, and new game mechanics to further enhance the play-style of the standard AC gameplay.

GOOD

Main story is interesting, I was always wondering what was going to happen next.
Jack the Ripper DLC is one of the best DLC campains I have ever played, exceeding my expectations greatly. Good enough to be a standalone game if it was just a bit longer...perfect length for DLC, though.
A few new game mechanics (grappling line, carriage driving, etc.)
Signature AC stealth and parkour.

BAD

Modern Abstergo story realizes just how pointless it is by having almost nothing to do with the main story...maybe this should be listed under the Good, lol, I always thought the "modern" story was needless drivel.
While the environment of Old London is really cool, graphics overall prove to be lackluster. NPCs that aren't main characters look drab and unpolished; the buildings all look dusty, and not in the sense of dirt, but rather lack of vibrance.
Same signature AC stealth and parkour comes with same signature AC glitchy maneuvering. In one instance, I died multiple times because my character would ignore the handholds not inches away, and simply plummet to the ground.
Animation glitches: free-running across thin air, executing enemies without touching them.

CONCLUSION

Assassin's Creed: Syndicate has the same old formula as most AC games, as well as the same old problems. But, it's far from bad, it's actually rather enjoyable to play...highly recommend the Jack the Ripper expansion as well.
Game currently runs on Steam for $40, Jack the Ripper is $15, it's worth it for both.

Topus
146 products in account
0
3 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
194.6 hrs on record
Posted: 19 June
"What's this, Greenie? Assassin Christmas?"

Haha! I love this game. It's also considered the last "classic style" AC game. I will never understand why people had a problem with it. There was a lot of innovation. Some reasons are understandable. Others are just short-sighted, in my opinion. Let's talk about the parkour. It's nowhere near as complex as in AC: Unity, even though it uses the same system. A lot of Unity's stylish animations were removed, and freedom of movement was also removed, such as allowing "dangerous jumps" to be performed. As in, jumping from heights that would kill you, but being able to save yourself by performing a manual ledge grab / breakfall. It's understandable that Victorian London's architecture and style doesn't allow for parkour as complex and satisfying as Paris. The buildings and streets are simply too spaced out. Yes, I live in UK, and yes, I used to do parkour as a kid. It was hard to find decent spots that weren't busy, corporate property where you'd likely get kicked out of LOL! xD For that, AC: Syndicate's solution was the Hidden Blade's latest attachment, the grappling hook, acting as a climbing tool or zip-line to get from point A to point B as fast as possible. It feels very satisfying to use, it looks cool, it fits the Steampunk vibe, but at the same time, it kinda removes the need for classic parkour. I enjoy the faster-paced combat and animation diversity. The combos, the multi-kill system, etc... with unique weapons such as deadly canes, kukris and brass-knuckles. Anyone complaining about having to hit an enemy 50 times before they die... do me a favour and buy yourself some higher quality gear, will you? And some perks that focus on bringing enemies down to "Near-Death State" quicker. It literally takes 1 or 2 hits to kill an enemy in hand-to-hand combat if you know the game's mechanics and progression system. And you can even insta-kill enemies with your first strike if the right conditions are met, taking down an entire group of enemies in seconds. Come on, people... first you complained that the classic, older AC games were too simple and repetitive, and the counter-kill system made everything too easy and automatic...

Now, AC Syndicate's stealth and NPC AI works much better than Unity's. In Unity, the tools (smoke bombs, etc..) were your solution to everything. And I'm not complaining. It felt amazing. But in Syndicate, everything just feels snappier. I like the improvements a lot. I think the gameplay is one of the best things about Syndicate. Manually and silently aiming throwing knives at enemies' heads feels good. Zip-line assassinations bring a whole new dynamic to the gameplay and creativity of tackling a stealth situation. Kidnapping is introduced as both a stealth mechanic and mission objective. The former allows for any enemy not aware of Jacob/Evie, to be kidnapped and used as a form of social blending, allowing access to restricted areas. Whistling is back, and it's very useful. There's different methods of transportation (GTA-style) like horse-drawn carriages with a lot of variety in terms of size, durability, speed and control, which you can ram into other carriages to cause mayhem and destruction or hop onto the roof of your carriage to shoot your enemies, or to jump onto another enemy's carriage and hijack it. There's better side activities which aren't just you going around stealing items / killing dudes. The Murder Mysteries are genius work! They're much more complex and dynamic than AC Unity's, with new mechanics such as tracing the trajectory of a projectile that killed the victim back to its original, potential location, only to find a firearm hidden nearby, etc.. That sort of thing. There's gang allies that you can recruit and call for help, which is reminiscent of the early Ezio AC games, there's a bigger presence of kids than in any other AC game, so the world feels a bit more alive and believable, and whoever thought to make your hideout on a moving train that goes around the city is a genius. It feels so good to return there in between missions, collect income, etc.. and see your twin (which makes comments on your attire and weapons) as well as other side characters chilling about. So cozy.

Let's talk a bit about the narrative. The modern day. What's Abstergo up to this time?

In 2015, Bishop contacts the Helix Initiate to help herself and fellow Assassins Shaun Hastings and Rebecca Crane locate a Piece of Eden, apparently hidden in a vault, somewhere in London. Through camera drones, the Initiate watches the pair of Assassins conduct their field work and download the memories of the twins Jacob and Evie Frye. The artefact is The Shroud, actually teased back in AC2 (The truth puzzles, I believe) the very same piece of cloth that "resurrected" Jesus Christ. Cool lore. Abstergo plans to find it. Instead of cloning a member of the First Civilisation like they planned to in AC Unity, they intend to recreate one from scratch using the Shroud's cellular level healing ability inside their secret laboratories. Very disturbing, but very interesting. The Assassins must stop them before it's too late, because Juno is still out there after Desmond set her free back in 2012. Collect Helix Glitches in game and you will unlock new Present Day Assassin Intel and backstories related to The Shroud, that date back to the Italian Renaissance and the Auditore Villa. Nice throwbacks :) The present-day story, even though there's no gameplay unfortunately, is still pretty great. The action sequences during pre-rendered cutscenes are badass and very high quality, using the full CGI character models, and it's nice to see familiar faces such as Shaun and Rebecca reminiscing about Desmond and how they miss him. Real fan service. Master Assassin Galina Voronina also makes an appearance (she is known from the AC comic books) and helps them take the fight to the Templars, even saving their lives from Otso Berg's elite Sigma Team. Again, very, very badass, especially the end cinematic with that music.

The game has the player take on the role of an Initiate, same as in Unity, as they explore the story of the twin Assassin protagonists, Jacob and Evie Frye, both of whom are playable at any time during the open world exploration and side missions, but they both have their own unique missions too during the main story. Jacob, a brash and charismatic lad searching for glory and the spilling of Templar blood, much like a younger Ezio, and Evie, a smart, beautiful, by-the-book sort of lass who likes to apply knowledge and a more tactical approach to her mission assignments. There is a nice dynamic between the two, typical of twins, with Jacob getting slightly more screen time during main missions as he's the one that gets to cut down Templar after Templar in the best "black-box" style Assassin's Creed mission structures yet! While Evie searches for a Piece of Eden and cleans up after Jacob.. xD The two arrive in London in 1868, as the Industrial Revolution reaches its climax, bringing its lot of inequality and poverty in a city controlled by the Templars and Grandmaster Crawford Starrick, which is a very likeable antagonist, in my opinion. To stop their rule, the Fryes will take over the organised crime in an effort to gather an army, called The Rooks by Jacob, and free London while helping the working folk, such as eliminating forced child labour and liberating London's boroughs. The game can be pretty light-hearted at times, with Jacob making sarcastic comments in every sentence and Evie calling him out for being immature. I love it, and it was much needed, especially after Unity's rather tragic love story / Shakespearean-play kind of ending. I recommend!

Jack the Ripper DLC is excellent. A must play! A disturbing, almost horror-like, cinematic experience set 20 years after the main game. The Last Maharajah DLC is an abomination, though. While interesting in concept, it's extremely buggy and "low-budget"..

Posted: 28 June, 2017
having put in around 50 hours or so offline (moved house and lost internet for a week, alas) and come to around 95% completion right now I think I can fairly come to the conclusion that this, along with Rogue are my least favourite AC games.

I'll skip any kind of review of the story because it's not really that memorable at all, the side missions with famous people like Karl Marx and Charles Darwin are much more memorable than the main plot.

The grappling hook...oh the grappling hook. It destroys any sense of exploration in Syndicate because you'll find yourself zipping across the rooftops to get to objectives as quickly as possible when you're not even lazier using fast travel; you'll never really get to know the map like I felt I did in Unity which was great, knowing where to go without using the minimap gives you a great sense of accomplishment and you have to give props to the devs for that. I've lived in London and know the city very well and I still felt disconnected from the city/map in Syndicate even though I know my way around (of course the scale here is smaller but landmarks etc are in roughly the same place). Missions are spread out too far and getting from one place to the other requires no effort when you have fast travel and a grappling hook - or of course the carriages which give you the annoying "follow me" line because apparently we're 5 year olds who need our hands held through the entire game...

The one thing this game really has going for it is that you have two characters to play and for the most part you get to choose unless you're doing character specific story missions where you're forced to use one or the other. Which is a shame because I would've gladly played the entire game with Evie since Jacob is at the very least as insufferably macho as Ezio. At least when leveling up as Evie those points became available automatically for Jacob too - even though I only played as him when I was forced to. He's my least favourite male lead in the entire series.

Since AC3 I've only truly enjoyed Unity and the Chronicles series. I know Black Flag is everyone's favourite after AC2 but for me the over reliance on island hopping and ships was a real drag. Too much pirating, not enough Assassin-ing. Thank god Assassin's Creed: Origins will be out soon and hopefully a grand return to the roots of the series. I've played every single AC title and if I were to speak to anyone about the series that hadn't played it but was looking to start - I would absolutely suggest skipping Assassin's Creed Syndicate.

Recommended
30.9 hrs on record
Posted: 30 October, 2021
Overall Rating: 4/5
Good:
Conquering territories is a nice way to level up your character. It's a grind but fun and has a purpose. It also relates to the plot which is nice.
The grappling gun works well and let's you traverse the city quickly.
Stealth is a bit better than previous games and can be used as a tactic.
They story is light on but enjoyable, it doesn't take itself too seriously. If you are looking for realism you're gonna have a bad time as you'll be on jaunty side missions protecting Karl Marx and Charles Darwin.
What I did like about this one is the story progresses at a good pace and doesn't feel like it drags. You don't get stuck grinding just to complete a mission.

The Bad:
Still doesn't have a fully realised stealth system, enemies are eagle eyed and there's not much cover you can utilise. Seems like a no brainer for assassin's Creed to have better stealth because you are assassinating people more often than not.
Lacks non lethal weapons or easy ways to knock out enemies. Often you're just killing everyone and everything.
Combat is more arcade like with combos and multipliers. It's smoother but a bit too simplistic and button mashy. I would have preferred something more like in unity where you engage with the combat by dodging, parrying and striking instead of mashing attack and dodging occasionally.
Too many high powered guns later in the game which you can exploit with the data reload skill. After a while you just start shooting everything.
The main characters are ok but could have been fleshed out a bit more, not much depth here.
 

HAN_AbdÃ¼lhamid
80 products in account

4 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
68.7 hrs on record
Posted: 28 March, 2017
After playing Black Flag I was afraid I'd never be able to enjoy an Assassin's Creed game again if it didn't include awesome naval warship combat. Well, Syndicate didn't have any warships, but it was amazingly fun without them.

At times this game felt like Grand Theft Carriage. The inclusion of horse drawn carriages lead to some of the most fun and chaotic moments in the game. There's nothing like hijacking a rival gangs supply delivery, and the high speed chases that ensue. It's reminiscent of the chariot battles in Ben Hurr. Smashing your carriage into enemies carriage, running them off the road, and jumping on the roof while your horses keep running so you can attempt a drive by shot to enemy drivers. It's a great adrenaline rush.

I also love the new main characters. The brother & sister duo of Jacob and Evie Frye are as charismatic and likable as Edward Kenway. Instead of being pirates, the siblings are street gang leaders. Battling rival Templar gangs for territorial dominance is the majority of the games side missions focus. You'll be doing various task to sabotage the rival gangs operations including - freeing children from poor labor conditions, hijacking cargo delivery, kidnapping leaders, to good ole assassinations. Once you do enough of these missions you'll draw out the enemy gangs general in a final Gangs of New York style brawl to determine who runs the region.

I really enjoyed the side missions and gang wars. I never grew tired or bored despite the inevitable repetitious nature of open world side missions.

This is certainly a great Creed game. The greatest? No, that's still Black Flag for me. However, Syndicate is a damn close second. I'm now excited again about the AC franchise, and looking forward to the next era.

31.2 hrs on record
Posted: 17 July, 2017
Now, this is the first Assassin's Creed game I've played on the PC which is in itself a jarring switch of controls, but the games have always had problematic hangups on free-running where you suddenly find yourself romantically attached to a wall and unable to move on, or you spontaneously decide that the railing fifteen feet behind you is more appealing to land on than the pathway in front of you mid-race, and those feel more present on the PC than console. I haven't made it very far into the game's story, because I'm the type who tries to do all of the available map-opening side quests first so I won't comment on it. Mechanically I do not recommend this game.

During a kidnapping event, grabbing Jamie Something-or-Other who appeared to have nothing more to his list of crimes than a frequent urge to peep into people's windows and bang on their door if he didn't like their utensil placement or something. The problem here is that he was scripted to walk up the five steps to their doorway and just sit there in his animations for twenty seconds at a time before moving a foot to the side and doing it again. To kidnap someone you need to approach them stealthily, from behind. Now I was crouched with my hood up sniffing this man's bottom, a greeting I believe is still customary in Modern London, and I wasn't prompted to kidnap him nor could I despite him following his scripted placement and me following the instructions to the letter.

Then we get to the problems with knives and weapons, and I understand the mechanic where your lack of spit-shining your knives so that they menacingly glimmer in the sunlight as they spiral towards your victims head for more damage than the layman's unpolished murder utensil, but I honestly feel that it has no purpose in a game that tries to be more "realistic" in its combat weight. These men are wearing a bowler hat at most on their head, and you're telling me that the sweat of their brow is so significantly dense that it utterly deflects my knife as they scoff at me? Not to mention that if you do manage to stealthily kill a man with a knife, or by dropping barrels on him by severing their rope with a knife, all of their friends see the corpse and instantly predict the wind, trajectory, and velocity of your knife to know where you're standing five seconds later five stories up on a brick shanty. I've failed stealth missions entirely based on that, killing a man from a rooftop with a thrown knife, walking down the cobbled street for a spot of tea, and then his friends all showing up on my radar simultaneously shaking their fists and telling me I have no business here from twelve blocks over.

For a series about stealth, the amount of times I've been detected by not being witnessed doing a stealth kill is astonishing. Not to mention the times I've been told to kill a leader undetected, lure their guard away with a whistle and kill them, then watch as another man spawns right before my eyes from a bowler hat brought in with the breeze and blows my cover as his first action in this mortal coil.

Without any opinion on the story, I can't recommend this game based on how utterly unwieldy it is to play. It doesn't feel good to control, the stealth is a dice roll at best, and parts of the game force you to upgrade items that shouldn't need upgrading because of their core purpose.

With all of that said though, I've passed the steam deadline on refunds so I'll probably slog through the game for completion's sake alone.

Edit : I've tried to play more of it and my opinion on it only gets worse. I'm not going to put any more time into this miserable game. I'm being instantly killed at full health by a random grunt two levels below me after I've maxed out the health upgrades possible this early on, you don't get any items back when you die which means if you've been killed by the Second Coming like I keep experiencing your odds of surviving get infinitely worse and I'm not even on a mission I'm just trapped in this temporal flux of hatred.

Not Recommended
23.9 hrs on record
Posted: 2 October, 2017
Don't get me wrong, I love the victorian/steampunk genre, I was so excited to play this game because of that one reason.
I pretty much like every genres (the location, the time, the story, etc)s Assassin's Creed has been using so far.

So, what's the problem with this game? Many things unfortunately.

I'll start off with the positive:
-Really great music if you love classical/victorian era music, it makes the atmosphere way much more better, really, it is probably the best point of this game.
-A map that has the right size for an Assassin's Creed game.
-Nice graphics and textures but... See negative.
-Principal assassins (Jacob and Evie) looks pretty cool and promising enough, so does the other characters, such as Henry Green, perhaps not as much as Ezio and Altair but he looks pretty decent, not as much as Jacob and Evie though.
-Throwing knives

Here's the neutral points, depending on the whom, it could be a negative point, for me, it is but it's not that bad anyway:
-There are no swords in this game.
-Not every costumes from previous games are available, unfortunately, not a disaster, but would have been good to have them.

Now, the negative:
-Ugly textures not only from far but from close too, graphics are okay, they're not that great actually, textures are pretty good but depends of what and the lod (distance view) is kinda horrible considering the age of the game, plus it is nothing like in the E3 but that is to be excepted from Ubi isn't?

Now the even more negative that makes me hate this game more than liking it:
-Microtransactions, you've heard that right, optional? Hey kid, I don't care that it is optional or not, it's already an overpriced game, why should there be any cancerous crap like this in a game like this?
-Gameplay has been dumb down, there are some good things about it but it's too easy that it is too hard, get what I mean? Probably not, the gameplay is too basic, I don't know if it is me, but there are things you cannot do anymore.
Double air assassination? I don't know what's wrong with it but it seems like you have to be really close to the two persons otherwise it won't work like in the previous Assassin's Creed games, it's really bad.
Jumping and running, what the heck is this? Can't you just keep the formula of Assassin's Creed II: Brotherhood? That one was way better than the ones we are getting recently. I mean, you could jump anywhere and dies from it while in this game, it won't let you jump, like some kind of anti-noob measure? Yeah no, but thanks, no, I don't want that crap.
Running and jumping feels so simplified, if you want to drop off you have to repeatly click "E" (default keyboard key) instead of holding it once and dropping (and die if you're too high) like you could in the previous games.
I could be making a big paragraph about the gameplay that would take me 1 hour to write but I'll end it here, you get the idea of what I'm trying to say about the gameplay of this game.


In the end, I would suggest this game, but the gameplay is so simplified, I don't like it, I can't stand it, otherwise, it looks like a good game with flaws here and there.
Don't buy it for more than 15$.

If you are new to the series and or are a casual, you'll probably love this game if you love the steampunk/victorian era but if you are a previous Assassin's Creed players who likes the gameplay of the first games then this will be a downside to you.

Honestly, I would except the up-coming games to get more complexe and harder, but I was wrong, they really went mainstream, Assassin's Creed should not be an easy game, it should be an challenging game with a complexe gameplay, or at least, that's my opinion.


Music overall 9.5/10 - This is for the OST that has no singing, don't really care about the OST that has singing.
Characters overall 8.7/10 - Nothing more to say about that.
Graphics/textures 6.5/10 - Could and should have been way better than that, we are PC gamers after all, not console gamers.
Map design and size: 8.5/10 - It is pretty detailed and its size is just good for a game like this, would have been great to have more (small) maps than one though.
Microtransactions -10/10 - What are they doing here? Feeding Ubi greediness and incompetence?
Gameplay and difficulty 4/10 - Try again next year.

SPOILER ALERT.

Assassin's Creed: Syndicate

"It's a bloody marvelous time to be alive. An age of invention. So many clever blokes dreaming up impossible machines. Sorting away more gold than Queen Victoria herself. But none of those schillings ever make it to the pockets of the poor devils whose blood is spilt building this glorious empire. The working class sleep walks through life unaware of the machine that drives them. Let's wake them up then, shall we?"


AC Syndicate was apparently meant to improve Assassin's Creed franchise again. Successfully, I dare say.
Its story is great, lacks bigger plot twists, but that's not what AC games are about. On the other hand, you can play as Jacob or Evie, depends on your choice. That allows you to somehow choose your playstyle, although Syndicate is a well balanced combination of stealth and fighting.

Also there's a lot of things you can do, whether it's freeing London, robbing trains and carriages, killing Templar leaders, collecting hidden objects, playing side missions, taking part in illegal carriage races or street fights. And of course, the main questline. Well, I'm not even mentioning the DLC's.

Then there's the city of London itself. Simply outstanding with its industrial beauty, wide streets full of people, high buildings you can climb on and lots of accessible rooms and houses. London is just beautiful and as alive as it can possibly be.
AC Syndicate also has an atmospheric and well composed soundtrack, and according to all those things mentioned above, very high enjoyability, thus being the best Assassin's Creed game in my opinion.

JML
22 products in account

24 people found this review helpful
5 people found this review funny 0

Recommended
235.1 hrs on record
Posted: 25 November, 2015
Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a historical action-adventure open world stealth video game developed by Ubisoft Quebec and published by Ubisoft. Set within London in 1868 during the Industrial Revolution, the story follows twins Jacob and Evie Frye as they navigate the corridors of organized crime during the Victorian era and fight against the established order, controlled by the Templars. The game retains the series' third-person open world exploration as well as introducing new traveling systems and refined combat and stealth mechanics.

Unlike its direct predecessors but like the first two main games in the series, Syndicate does not feature any multiplayer gameplay. Assassin's Creed Syndicate marks the first time in the series where you can freely switch between two different protagonists. It is also the first main entry in the series to feature a playable female protagonist. Male lead Jacob Frye is meant to be more of a hot-headed brawler, specialized in close combat, while his twin sister Evie is strong in stealth and relies on her intelligence and wit.

The Assassins' main weapons this time around include brass knuckles, a compact revolver, a cane sword and the traditional Nepalese curved kukri knife and combat is faster-paced than before. Additionally new travelling systems make their debut in the game, such as a rope launcher which allows the you to rappel up structures as well as create a zip-line between buildings, and carriages, which can all be piloted or simply occupied by you, and trains. London in the game is approximately 30% larger than Paris in Unity and consist of seven boroughs: Westminster, the Strand, the City of London, Whitechapel, the Thames, Southwark and Lambeth.

Overall I think Assassin's Creed Syndicate is a massive improvement and perhaps the best AC game since AC II not just because of the gameplay and the story, but also the port. It runs very smoothly and the graphics are just beautiful, I suggest you play around with the settings to get the best performance possible. It hardly has any game breaking bugs or glitches that can prevent you from being able to complete certain missions. If your getting an AC game I suggest you go for this as it will absolutely blow you away without a single doubt at all!.

The story is great, the graphics are brilliant.... BUT!! The control system in this game completely destroys the game, I mean it breaks it completely for me. I haven't been this infuriated and frustrated since I played "Primal Rage" on the SNES when I was like 12.

Some examples would be, when your navigating a building face and want to climb up, dependant on the camera angle you will either jump sideways when you want to climb or you will scale down the building when you want to go sideways. I've also noticed that if you want to go into a small gap where say your objective is with a wall either side of it, the character will snap to the top of the wall on either side, unless you walk slowly into it. Obviously when your hurrying its annoying. I've also noticed a fair amount of bugs despite this game having been out for nearly 2 years now, NPC's falling through the floor on the train and spawning at wierd angles occassionally.

As london is tightly packed in some areas, the character is constantly snapping to walls or jumping up onto things when you don't want them too. I couldn't possibly imagine what would happen if they set this game in modern day Tokyo, I think every blood vessel in my head would explode!!

Jinxbear
267 products in account
0

Recommended
29.5 hrs on record
Posted: 16 July, 2018
Oh bugger, it's Victorian London.

AC Syndicate tosses you into 1868 Britain, or really just London, in a time of massive industrial growth, expansion overseas, and... a really unpleasant underside that you get to see quite a lot of in this game. London is quite well detailed, and it has quite a bit of internal diversity depending on what part of the city you are in. Which means that the differences between the rich areas like Westminister are a world apart from the dirty and poor places like Whitechapel. I don't recall there being an AC game before this one that had NPC children, but there are tons of them in these poor areas begging for food and living in miserable conditions. I knew plenty about this era beforehand of course, but it still felt rather uncomfortable seeing it in game. Makes you remember that it was that sort of world that spawned socialism, which initially was just a wish for poor people's lives to not be completely â¥â¥â¥â¥.

Oh, and the Thames is brown, which made me feel really gross everytime my character fell in it. >_>

We also get the usual round of historical figures that has become a staple of AC games. You have lots of side-quests where you do things for the likes of Charles Dickens, Charles Darwin, and Karl Marx among others. Also you get Alexander Graham Bell acting sorta like Leonardo Da Vinci did in AC2 by making gadgets and tools for you. The difference however is that while in past AC games these historical figures were nice surprises and/or weaved into the main plot quite well with the aforementioned Da Vinci being a great example of this. But in Syndicate... it feels as if most of these historical figures just show up to say hi and don't really amount to much. And while I might smirk at the fact that pretty much every story set in the Victorian Era has Queen Victoria herself show up at some point, her appearances was one of the few that didn't feel like just having a famous person tossed in for its own sake. The famous feuding politicans Disraeli and Gladstone along with Florence Nightingale also fit into the story (reasonably) well. But as a whole this old part of the AC series just kind of fell flat in Syndicate.

Having played multiple AC games during the past ~2 weeks, Syndicate seems to me to be a culmination of everything this series has going for it and what is dragging it down. Assassination funtimes, immersive settings, and (mostly) competent gameplay mixed with its weaker gameplay parts, stupid amounts of side activities, and a map filled with collectibles that annoy me more than make me wish to seek them out. Oh, and they kept the microtransactions from Unity. â¥â¥â¥â¥ Ubisoft.

If this review seems... uninspired or that I'm just going through the motions because I write a review for every game I play after I finish them, then that is probably no accident. AC Syndicate isn't exactly boring, but it feels like stagnation for a series that has run on a bit too long and badly needs another game like Black Flag to revive it. I actually found myself wandering away from playing this game and poking that pirate funtime game a bit instead. That another game in the same series I had already played extensively was pulling my attention away from the game I'd never played before is a rather bad sign. Admittedly this may be because I played it right after having finished Rogue, one of the better entries in the series, but Syndicate just... wasn't all that interesting.

It's not the worst AC game I've played though. As stale as it felt, Syndicate still did immersion very well and had its neat moments. It didn't irritate me like AC3 or Unity did with its poorer quality following the Ezio funtimes or huge missed opportunities respectively. But even then those two games despite their flaws flaws at least kept me interested enough to be upset about their failures. Syndicate has only one big plus in the form of its immersive setting but has the problem of being on the boring side. But now that I'm really thinking about it, Syndicate itself isn't what was boring but rather the series itself due to how "standard" this game felt.

So I'm once again thinking "maybe" rather than "yes or no" when it comes to recommendations. But as stale as the series feels after having finished it, Syndicate itself is alright. So i'll give it a "yes" but with the asterisk that I really don't feel interested in the AC series much anymore.

Perhaps I shouldn't have played three of them back to back in the span of ~10 days. With the passage of some time, I might be nicer to this game. But for now, I need to do something else. >_>

Syndicate is an improvement over Unity and it is generally a pretty fun game if you can get past the repetitive structure. Itâs one of those games where you have to take over piece by piece of the map to progress by doing repetitive and simple missions to eventually liberate London. From a story perspective itâs by far the most simple in the series, Itâs just Jacob and Evie doing what they have to do to take over London without really any twists and turns in the story or obstacles that make that objective difficult. They are pretty much unstoppable, there arenât any stakes in the story because Jacob and Evie are always on top of every situation and there arenât any threatening hurdles to stop them from being at the top which doesnât create any tension or intensity in the story. Because Jacob and Evie single handedly take over London it removes the more grounded tone that the first few games had which kind of separates this game from the rest of the franchise because itâs by far the most light hearted. It feels a little tone deaf however because the game also tries to be serious and it still attempts that historical relevancy of the other games and it doesnât really work that well. The thing what makes the story better than Unity at least is that Jacob and Evie are likable characters that have a good dynamic and they keep the cutscenes entertaining to watch. The modern day stuff is still really bad though and not even worth paying any attention to.

The setting is ok, itâs not as memorable or interesting as Venice or Rome for example. Itâs a good game overall and a step in the right direction after Unity.

Assassin's Creed in Victorian London, I went into it after the mess that is Unity without any hopes for a mindblowing experience, I found myself surprised, it's a lot more polished and diverse than Unity which made me play the game alot more than it's necessary to do every single thing.

The story is what normally save AC games, I got alot more interested in the characters in Syndicate, there's plenty of them, besides Evie and Jacob and their allies and enemies, there missions that have you working directly with characters from the time, such as Charles Dickens, Charles Darwin and Queen Victoria herself.

Posted: 25 March, 2016
Little Backstory of Assassins Creed Syndicate first, you play as the two main characters Jacob and Evie Frye who were trained by their father to be assassins. Through out the game you are working on taking out the templars that control the streets of London. Your main goal is to take out Crawford Starrick and take control of London for yourselves.

That's pretty much how I saw the game at least.

Assassins Creed Syndicate brings back parts of previous Assassins Creed games that haven't been seen for a while. The game is very entertaining for the most part, but can get to the point where it starts to drag on in the end. You gain experience through out playing the game that allow you to increase your combat skill, add additional perks to each character and unlock new items to use upon reaching new levels and completing sequences. You also have to look for items throughout London to upgrade you gang by giving them better weapons, horse carriages to drive around the city, and just making the stronger in general. The game includes a lot of the fighting style and combat mechanics as Unity and a few from Rogue.

Aesthetics, the game looks... well... decent. I'm not able to run it on the highest of settings but I can run it decently and it looks okay. I think they could have done a way better job on how this game looks even though it's during the "steampunk" era. Like Black Flag that game was absolutely gorgeous, this game is honestly kind of a let down to me personally when it comes to graphics but it still looks amazing and is fun to play.

All in all or TL;DR:
This game is fun and has a lot of exciting moments in and brings a whole new feel to the Assassins Creed Franchise in my opinion kind of like how Black Flag and Brotherhood change the series as a whole. I would recommend this game to anyone who is just looking for a really fun game to play that might take them around 40 - 50 hours to complete in total. I rate this game a solid 8.5/10 overall gaming aspects but for an Assassins Creed game it gets 9/10 from me. Nothing will ever be better than Black FLag and Brotherhood to me. If you haven't played those you need to do so.
