Not Recommended
4.1 hrs on record
Posted: 28 January, 2016
TL;DR: Crash to Desktop: The Game.

I'll begin by stating I am not an ardent fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise.

My first intallment in the franchise was Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood. Some will say that this was a highlight in the storied gaming series, and it certainly felt entertaining and refreshing for its time. Since playing and completing Brotherhood, I've longed to play another Assassin's Creed game despite varied successes.

I contemplated purchasing Assassin's Creed: Black Flag, but decided against it purely in opposition to its selling point: its naval exploration and combat focal points. I wanted a return to the exciting combat and incredible settings that Brotherhood (and many subsequent games) have aspired for.

That was my first mistake.

I had also wanted to give Assassin's Creed: Unity a chance... but decided against it due to overwhelmingly negative peer review. Still, the idea of a co-operative Assassin's Creed game is promising.

I decided that I had waited long enough. I had heard that Assassin's Creed: Syndicate attempts to capture what made Brotherhood so great. (You might even argue that Jacob Frye is emulating Ezio Auditore a little too much.)

That was my second mistake.

I went ahead and purchased the gold edition for the game with having put a little time and research into the product. I came in with relatively low expectations due to repeated failures in Ubisoft's past, but was pleasantly surprised by the prologue. Jacob and Evie Frye are fascinating characters and genuinely enjoyable to play for the most part.

However, this is not only an Ubisoft game, it's an Assassin's Creed game. What bugs and glitches I experienced at first were minor, at best, until the big one came. My hardware should have little trouble running this game on decent settings, yet despite that, I reached the infamous "Stage 3" train scene and fight.

This stage is known to cause immediate crashing, to which it has done to me aplenty. I cannot pass it, and in some cases, cannot even load to the main menu as a consequence of where my progress stopped.

Now, I dislike the idea of "thumbs down"ing a game due to a performance issue I cannot resolve on my part... However, in this case, I make an exception. It is an issue many have experienced and Ubisoft has not yet addressed with patching. Until this problem is resolved, I cannot -- in good faith -- recommend this game to my friends or the general public.

Alas... I had looked so forward to it.

It reminded me hugely of the Ezio trilogy, arguably the best Assassin's Creed games. The world feels perfect to travel across, the player characters are likable with each of them having their own goal for the creed.

Like the older AC games, especially the Ezio trilogy? Burnt by the recent ones? Give this one a go, definitely great fun and a return to what AC should be.

Recommended
45.8 hrs on record
Posted: 22 January, 2017
If your looking for a AC game with more guns and more focus on the assassin part of the story, look no further!

This game is a breakthorugh in the AC series, personally i enjoy more options with firearms in the game and i think that this game bridges the gap between flintlock era and the revolver era perfectly.

The game is short, in under 35 hours i finished the entire story line and did all the boroughs. i have not collected all the music boxes or anything else but the game can be compleated in 35 hours. if this a problem with you, you may want to look into DLC.

The voice acting is good, everyones accent is relistic and does not feel faked out, people in the game are historic (dickens ect) and they have good side quests to give you. the frye twins do feel somewhat gapped though, whomever you decide to play more with, its more of a burden to play with the other when forced to.

The main pro of this game is the customization, it has much more than any previous AC game, you can upgrade both frye twins, upgrade the gang, upgrade your hidden blade, clothes, canesword, kukuri, pistols, bombs,knives,darts everything. some of the upgrades are simple and basic but some of them for the gang are very helpful.

London...London london london.....This was a big let down for me, In all truth, Black Flag must be 3 of London put together. the city is not as large as one might think what makes it seem big is the fact that all the buldings are built like walls with no allyways so you have to use the roads if on foot. once you run roofs the city becomes very very small. Personally, black flag is much much larger than london, not to say london sucks, there are cool places to go, the Tower of London, the Palace, The Bank of England. but the map overall is very small.

Overall, i would reccommend this game to someone who likes the firearm side of the game, and the brutality. But! i would not buy this game for 40$ wait for it to go on sale and get it on sale. it does not offer enough replay value on its own to pay 40$ or more for the basegame.

Recommended
48.6 hrs on record
Posted: 29 December, 2015
First of all, let me start by stating that I have beaten the game (all the story missions and boss battles, but not all the side missions) and I have never felt so compelled at writing a review for a game, but Syndicate is different.

As an AC fan who has played every single AC game except for Rogue, I lost a lot of respect for the AC franchise after Unity due to its poor character development, crappy storyline, and glitched gameplays. As a result, I didn't expect Syndicate to be fun when I purchased this game, I simply bought it because I had the money at the end of the year and it was on sale (sort of). However, in my opinion, Syndicate is the best AC game so far. The game really emphasizes the personalities of Jacob and Evie, how their goals differ, how they argued and competed in a sibling rivalry way, and this really touched my heart. Ubisoft really stepped up their game (literally) and put in effort in the development, which is something that I have never felt in Unity. I liked their idea of liberating the city in another way, the blackbox kills, the city of London with her bustling engines and carriages, and their most interesting side missions involving historical figures yet (even though this has been done before in previous games, Syndicate did the best job). It seems like Ubisoft has finally realized their failure in the present-day storyline and has chosen to deviate from it quite a bit in Syndicate; to many this is even worse but to me it showed me that Ubisoft has realized their mistake and is now trying to fix it by using only short cutscenes instead of meaningless playthroughs, and this is a good start (cutscenes still show instereting story).

I was so drawn into this game that I completed the game in merely two days (two days, but I have 24 hours on record in two days), and I am by no means saying that the game itself is short even though it can be made longer. For me, the ending is not amazing, but it is by no means bad at all unlike IGN's review. As a fan, I dare say that I have moved on from Ezio, and that Jacob and Evie are my new favorite assassins. And yes, the Season Pass is worth the money for many reasons.

Pros:
Character development
Story
Evie's outfits
New & fast paced combat system
Unique and cool-looking weapons
Good graphics
Carriage riding and chasing
Two playable and (mostly) switchable Assassins
City liberation missions
Associates of the Brotherhood
Two types of NPC's: Aggressors and Protectors
Your gang that fights for you
Sibling rivalry
Rope launcher
New leveling system and skill tree
Badass, mobile Assassin Hideout
Smoothed parkour/free running
Amazing background music and soundtracks
Kidnapping people
Big yet useful world (unlike ACIII's frontiers)
British accents

Cons:
Jacob's outfits
No co-op
Can only wear hood when crouched/stealthed
Microtransactions still here even though not necessary
Poorly managed weapon rewarding system (missions unlock weapons w lower stats)
No significant difference in the skill trees
Evie's cape's animation (didn't notice until I saw other reviews, but yes it is like 20fps)
Minor glitch in the inventory where they mark some equipments as new items even though I have had them for a while

Overall, 9/10. Best AC game so far, good story, strong characters, new level systems, weapons, and skilss. Definitely would recommend. Season pass is worth it (for the first time). Buy the game and have fun.

Recommended
56.7 hrs on record
Posted: 8 March, 2019
After the tragedy that is AC Unity, Syndicate comes as a breath of fresh air.
Evie and Jacob start as an engaging duo with different sets of abilities that really affect gameplay but don't limit the player; it is possible to be stealthy with Jacob and brawly with Evie with no major inconveniencies. The means of transportation are varied and equally fun, at first I was a bit put off by the carts' lack of stability but soon enough I was feeling awfully gilty for rampaging the streets, and trust me... you'll want to roam these streets. Although fast travel is possible, it is almost sacrilegious to not experience the beautiful and well-built Victorian London.
It is true, most missions are rather repetitive, but BOY, they are so much fun! I haven't had this much fun in a AC game since Brotherhood.

Syndicate, however, is not flawless. The story goes really well until 70% of the plot when suddenly things start to get rushed and the characters loose some of their appeal; the last arguments and dialogues between Jacob and Evie make no sense. Mediocre characters (Pearl) get too much screentime while better ones don't get enough (Roth), the final battle is easy and very anticlimatic.

Overall I had a really good time with this game, but I understand why it may not please everyone.

Recommended
58.1 hrs on record
Posted: 24 March, 2018
I've been a fan of the Creed series for some time, so it was inevitable that I play this. I put off playing this for nearly 2 years because I was exhausted after Unity. I didn't hate Unity -- I played it after it was fully patched and had a decent time -- but there's a lot of busy work filling up AC open-world games.

Syndicate contains a lot more of the same busywork as Unity. I loved the Victorian London era and the gang stuff - that seemed well themed and worked out decent. I liked the revamped fighting system and enjoyed riding around in carriages. I also enjoyed Evie as a playable character. I didn't care for Jacob as much - he came across as a one-note "sarcastic ass" character which is well-travelled territory in video games.

The gameplay is as you'd expect if you've played Unity or any other recent AC game - not much deviation from the formula. Expect to do lots of running, killing, sneaking, collecting and so on. In games past, I'd go for every objective and collectible. In Syndicate, I finally decided to give that up because it was just too much busy work and I've got other, better ways to spend my time than cracking open another few dozen random chests with barely anything useful in them.

The story is OK but weaker than most AC games. By way of comparison to Unity, the Ezio tales or Black Flag, it was lacking quite a bit in depth and emotion. The ending fell a bit flat for me and was a "that was it?!?" moment. It felt incomplete. Once the main story is done, you get missions for Queen Victoria. I did one and stopped because, again, exhaustion. I also played through the first bit of the Jack the Ripper story but couldn't get much farther in that. Interestingly, Evie looks wildly different to the point of being unrecognizable to me.

Achievements are handled strictly through Uplay, for better or worse. I'd prefer they use Steam achievements so I could see them better. Bringing up the Uplay overlay is the kiss of doom for controller players - you'll need a mouse/keyboard to navigate (or dismiss) the Uplay overlay. I played via streaming on a Steam Link, so this was personally annoying to me.

So - recommended? Yes, but reluctantly. If you love the AC games and their open-world, this is more of the same. It's not bad by any stretch, just more. That's also the biggest problem - it's a bit too much.

tl;dr 3 out of 5, barely. Definitely not bad, but a bit too much "been there, done that" with a slightly boring story.

Assassin's Creed Syndicate continues the epic strugel between the templar order and the Assassin's Creed. This time the strugel takes place during victorian london, where you play as Evie and Jacob Frye or the Frye twins. They come to london in the search of the pieaces of eden. So is the templars who already have its grip around london. So the frye twins decide to take to the criminal underworld and start their own gang. To overthrow the templar order in various ways. Assassin's Creed Syndicate offers the same kind of fredom as Assassin's Creed Black flag and you can roam around to do what ever you want. Illegal horse racing, Illegal fight clubs, chase after materials for new weapones and so forth. Or you could do your quests.

The biggest draw back however with Assassin's Creed Syndicate is that the game must be placed in your main hard drive. If not the game will be stuck at the splash screen. This problem seem to happen to virtually all Assassin's Creed games from what iÂ´ve know.

I would defentily recomend this to anyone either a fan of the series or someone wanting to play something historical, action packed and strategy filled game.

TL DR: This game is worth playing, because it is different from the other assassin creed games. It is unique, because you can switch between two characters most of the time and you are given a batman like grapple tool... What more could you ask for right?

This game is also less tedious than the other assassin creed games I've played. It's not like there's over 70 view points. It's not like you have to kill guards all the time, etc.
This is one of those games that looks amazing, has a great story which may even teach you a thing or two, is historically accurate, has decent combat which you for the most part cannot just faceroll ( at least not until you get the best gear in the game...) and even has enough rpg elements without feeling like a grind...

I usually get bored of ''tripple A'' titles in less than 40 min. This is one of the few games I've played for about 50-70 hours and gotten 80% completion in. And after all that, I can confidently say it was worth the time.

Depol
363 products in account
0
6 people found this review helpful
2 people found this review funny 0

Recommended
62.0 hrs on record
Posted: 10 December, 2015
I cannot recommend this game highly enough. Ubisoft learned from Unity's failings, and has crafted an AC game that is as much fun as any AC has been since Brotherhood or Black Flag. I have played every main AC game, and completed them all, except for AC3 (which was a debacle) and Liberation, which I just lost interest in.

1868 London (and a quick jaunt to 1916!) is a wonderful place to explore. Sure, it's really a Dickensian nightmare, but it feels so real! I really did feel like I was walking through a living city, something I haven't felt since Revelations' Constantinople. The city is the sort of place you want to just wander around and look at! Trafalgar Square, the Tower, Piccadilly Circus, Parliament; all of these are places to go and marvel at!

The gameplay is likewise fantastic. The fighting is as fluid as it's ever been, and despite having all the same AC fighting issues as the rest of the series, it's still a blast to fight your way through a group of Templars. My only complaint is that choosing your fist as a weapon has been removed from the engine. That means those poor Bobbies are getting gutted just for doing their job. It's not as bad as the bar "fight" from Unity, but a lack of a fist option seems silly, when really, sometimes you just want to knock the guy down.

The only real gameplay issue I have is the carriage driving. Apparently, horses in Victorian London were pretty damned tough! I can race down the sidewalk in a carriage, knocking over iron-lamp posts with impunity, and the horses are cool with that. There are only a few missions requiring the use of a carriage, and I despised them all. Thankfully, they're quickly done, and mostly easy.

I am 50 hours into this game. I've completed the main storyline, the Queen Victoria missions you get after that, and am now in the midst of the 1916 missions. The 1916 mission, set in and around Tower bridge, are probably several hours worth of play, on their own, and a fascinating look into the death of the Victorian/Edwardian world.

And you know what? There's more to come. The Last Maharajah missions are coming, and the Jack the Ripper DLC.

I spent $120cdn on this game. I can honestly say, I have not spent money this well on a game in many, many years! (Though admittedly, XCOM2 is gonna swallow up hundreds of hours of my life....)

crebby
576 products in account
0
3 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
57.9 hrs on record
Posted: 14 April, 2021
I've played all of the main series (not counting the 2.5D spinoffs). After playing Origins, I decided to come back and play some I'd missed, like Unity (bought from Ubisoft directly) and Syndicate. Unity was not a good game, even setting aside performance issues. Boring story, bland characters, and really boring and repetitive gameplay. Syndicate, on the other hand, is a really quality entry into the series and I think the strongest one since AC2 or maybe Black Flag. It is obviously the last one of the series to retain the old formula of staying within a single city and lots and lots of parkour. I love the newest three games, but they are so wildly different in gameplay, that I won't consider them to be in the same family.

The good -

Well-written protagonists and their varying abilities let you cater to whatever gameplay style you want. I generally preferred playing Evie due to stealth, but Jack definitely rocks fights.

"Attack the outpost" missions are varied and enjoyable, more than other typical Ubisoft offerings that came before this one. While each type generally has a formula, they are still fun and provide some challenges at times.

The flavor and atmosphere of Victorian England is well-done. Smoky, rainy, crowded, dirty. The river traffic is fun to interact with, too, hopping from one boat to the next like Frogger.

Fights are well-done and visceral, particularly as your skills develop. NPCs do employ different fighting styles and fights can quickly go the wrong way if you're sloppy.

More environmental options for kills or stealth.

The zipline is a little immersion-breaking as well, but it makes getting around London a ton easier and is a great QOL improvment - no more wasting time climbing up the side of something.

Using your gang as backup is fun, effective, and they can be upgraded in multiple ways.

The bad -

The "bosses" are not that memorable, outside of the endgame boss and one of his lieutenants.

Carriage chases are annoying, because the streets are so crowded.

Fast travel always takes you to the top of a building and you wind up have to jump off, blah blah. Why not just take the player to the front door?

The camera locks to the player during certain sequences and it's annoying because you want to look down the street or your next objective, etc.

NPC levels feel a little odd in how they relate to player abilities. I never had a good sense of what they actually meant.

The ugly -

No "choices matter" in the game. This is jarring, because the characters often comment on the outcome of certain actions, but the player has no agency to choose a different path. The AC series has never really been known for that, but it's always been a glaring issue that really stands out in this game.

It doesn't really effect gameplay much, but the trains just seem odd in the game. They go around a loop like a model railroad. Some weird immersion-breaking moments there.

NPCs just react oddly to a dead body in their midst - "Ah, you were a good soldier. Now back to pacing aimlessly." You'd think they'd be a little more alarmed, call in help, something. Kind of immersion-breaking as well.

Overall, though, if you like the AC series, it's well worth getting, especially on a discount. I got my enjoyment out of it and am now moving on to Odyssey again, but don't have any regrets about playing this one unlike some others (looking at you, Rogue and Unity). If you've never played the AC series before, but like action games, it is maybe a good starting point as it is not as dated as the older entries from a technical perspective.

300 products in account

8 people found this review helpful

Not Recommended
58.5 hrs on record
Posted: 21 May, 2020
I hated this game. The PC keyboard/mouse controls are insanely overly complicated, not intuitive, not user-friendly. You use the same letter keys for multiple things, and if you hold them slightly too long, or hit them too quickly, you end up doing something completely different than you want to.

Although there are fast-travel points, you can't actually use them any time you're in the middle of a mission/quest. Which is ridiculous. Your hideout is a train, which moves very slowly and if you've got a mission across the city, it takes forever to get there, no matter which travel method you use.

The carriage driving is also terrible. The controls are too sensitive and there's no way to modulate speed in a reasonable way, so you end up smashing into things and taking corners far too fast, without being able to easily navigate around obstacles or NPCs.

And speaking of NPCs... Many, many missions have an insanely high amount of NPC characters, all of whom you have to overcome to achieve your goal or goals. And many of those NPCs are able to (and do) kill you in seconds, even when you stay within zones that are appropriate for your character skill limits. Redoing quests/missions over and over, simply because the leveling system is very badly done, is extremely frustrating.

The sneak option is really poorly implemented too. In other AC games, things like high shrubs and grass, or even a stack of crates, are usually decent places to hide. Not in this game. There's basically nowhere except roof-tops to hide, and even when you do, NPC characters climb up right after you in excessively large numbers. Which breaks the immersion of the game, because if you're crouched and hiding on a roof, how the hell can characters hundreds of feet below you, spot you and climb up to you instantaneously?

As well, I found the game to be very, very glitchy. Lots of stuttering, freezing, crashing. My hardware is more than capable of running it, but I had constant problems just getting the game to keep running.

I really like quite a few games in the AC franchise, but this one is awful. Repetitive game-play, unimaginative storylines, terrible keymapping, terrible in-game navigation, terrible NPC leveling. Huge waste of money, I wish hadn't purchased it. I'll tell you what I wish someone had told me... Even on sale, it's not worth it unless you enjoy being constantly annoyed and frustrated.

Not Recommended
23.8 hrs on record
Posted: 22 December, 2017
Assassin's Creed syndicate screams of a francaise that has ran out of ideas. Its no wonder they went for the reboot option following this title. How to drop the ball 101.
This is a bog standard Assassins Creed game with all the usual guff, smoke bombs, darts, ranged weapon, melee combat weapon. For some reason you also manage to loot Batman's personal stash and get hold of the Bat Grapnel as well.

The game plods along with a meh plot set in London. It seems like the creators wanted something of Gangs of New York meets Marry Poppins. The ideas are correct but London itself is uninspiring and one dimensional. I couldnt have really told you the poor parts from the rich parts even being a Historian and a resident of the United Kingdom. In short it all melded together. The gang fight missions were nice but you had to troil through the usual assassins creed missions first. In this case its assassination, kidnap and rescue. *Yawn* In most cases I did a mission if I strayed towards it but ignored it and did my usual fast travel method of Assasins Creed map movement.

Combat was pretty dismal as well, there are 3 weapons to choose from and the "dynamic" combat really boiled down to bash attack, dodge or quick shot when need to and stun the guy when he blocks. Gone are the timed counters from previous games. The was little timing or skill involved and I quickly found myself able to take out multiple opponents above my level with the sneaky character much less the combat wombat. Combat felt very forced and more of a button bash that it did in previous titles. The weapons available were also very un-inspiring a Knife, Knuckle dusters and a Sword Caine. I stuck with a Knife the entire game because the graphics of the others simply seemed a bit lame. There were the usual multiple kill options in combat but I think the game rolls a dice to decide if you execute this ability, sometimes it happened others it didnt.

Free running has always been a staple of Assassins Creed, in this title you now hold A to go up and X to go down. Sure if I wanted to skill jump parkour Id play Mirrors Edge, but this still feels like it takes all the flow and control away from you. To make matters worse the pre mentioned Bat Grapnel means you can fly about like Batman, instead of climbing a building one aimed shot can take you right to the top. Sure you move quicker but it just takes away the whole point and feel of Assassins Creed.

The game only uses four types of bad guy which sucked big time. Gang members, Guards, Templars and Police. Gone are the patrols of guards led by a captain or the guy with the big weapon etc. Again you button bash your way past these guys like you were... hmmm yes Batman.
The targets are also badly thought out, I will conceed the final bad guy Crawford Starrick has bags of bad guy charisma even if the final confrontation with him is more like a poorly thought out mini game than an actual finale.To top this off you even have a very predictable Bill the Butcher style guy leading the red enemy gang and he was voiced by Captain Jack Sparrow. *sigh*

I wanted to like Evie and Jacob Frye but both were quite one dimensional characters one violent the other sneaky *predictable*.
I really wanted to love this title but found the story pretty non existant. My usual too many weapons gripe was met with a not enough weapons complaint and I honestly couldnt wait for this to be over. The future / modern parts of the story were also lost to me and just served in wasting time, it doesnt fit what so ever and lets not even visit the World War I time line missions. Its as if a dev said "oh oh London lets cram everything we can in" That said Jack the Ripper DLC ( didnt bother) should have been part and parcel of the game although it was nice to see Spring Heeled Jack, although the game made no attempt to really explain this. So much potential in a historic and fine city lost.
If your a AC fan then go ahead and play this title but I wouldnt suggest getting it outside of a sale, if you havent played AC before avoid this one and play an earlier title you will find it much more satisfying!
Additional, having finished this title I decided to go back and play Assassins Creed 3 again. Can confirm there is more storyline and RP aspect in the first hour of gameplay than Syndicate's entire title. Disapointing.

Not Recommended
43.2 hrs on record
Posted: 12 May, 2018
First, let me say that I'm not recommending this game, not because of the game itself or anything in it, but because of Ubisoft's continued negligence of fixing bugs associated with this franchise.

The game itself is like other AC creeds. If you've played them and like them, this one shouldn't really be any different, other than being set in London. However, there is one new game mechanic that I thought was long-overdue that they finally included; early in the game you get a sort of hookshot tool which allows you to scale buildings almost instantly. It also allows you to move from rooftop to rooftop almost instantly as well. This is a HUGE time-saver. In the past, you could be on a roof and see something you need 2 rooftops away. If the city block was oddly shaped, sometimes to best way of proceeding was to climb down the building, then up and down the next building, and then up the 2nd building just to get the item. This was tedious as all hell. This new hookshot device eliminates most of that, and takes away one of my biggest complaints. That sort of thing was fun the first 2 or 3 games, but now it's just a chore. Good on you Ubisoft, for finally including that tool.

However, I'm still downvoting this game because it bugs out and stops running after every major sequence, and after some minor sequences as well. Apparently the issue has something to do with UPlay trying to update itself, and can be worked around by simply playing offline. What the hell, Ubisoft, fix your crap. This is now the 2nd AC game that had some sort of crashing bug in it, and although people complain about it regularly enough, Ubi continues to raise the middle finger high and proud, so I'm not buying any more of their games until they finally get their act together, and you shouldn't either. ;)

Recommended
28.2 hrs on record
Posted: 14 October, 2017
Recommend getting this game while on sale. It is your traditional Assassin's Creed game, does't change much in terms of mechanics besides the addition of the grapling hook. Although not required, using the grapling hook does make it easier to travel across the city.

The story is pretty mediocre, but still quite enjoyable. The one thing that I have always had a problem with is the way the Assassin's Creed games take you out of the world and into modern times. If you are like me and don't much care for the modern story, then you'll be glad to know that this game keeps it to a minimum. There is a few cutscenes but no gameplay during modern times. No need to walk around the Abstergo Lab doing repetitive mini games in order to progress the story.

Overall, if you take your time playing through the main story without doing any of the side quest such as freeing the boroughs, the game is roughly 20 hours. If you want to complete everything and get all the collectables, then this game can easily be 40 hours plus.

Good game, one of the more enjoyable Assasin's Creed games released.

I just completed the main story for this so about time I did a review.

Pro's:
Great story with a intresting historical plot.
Brutal yet satisfying combat.
New combo and multikill system for dispatching enemies.
Incredible open map portraying London very well.
Grapple hook... (It's in every AAA game now, don't act suprised)
Character switching.
Spot on voice acting and portrayl of historic figures.
Interesting villains with some having strange yet sophisticated morals and aims.

After running this game on two systems, One with a 750ti and one with a GTX 1080 I can tell you that they both run the game well. I found that on a lower card you are much safer lowering your resolution to 720p to get a very well deserved solid 60fps on medium graphical settings which still looks good. With a higher end card you're gonna be able to run this game incredibly well. Overall it is very well optimised.

Cons:
Some recycled animations from previous games.
Future/Current story lacks depth, insight and any kind of interesting aspects.
At least one story mission is a tail or listen mission which can be ended by silly NPC design paths.
Very lost plot path in the beginning previous tutor/assassin never checks up that you went to london throughout the whole story.
Ubisoft AI system... (You should know that every ubisoft game runs with AI that thinks like a mildly autistic frog with no legs)
Side mission very dull and repetitive
Ability to buy ingame money with a microtransaction store.

Overall the whole game was great, I enjoyed the main story, I found the side missions rather boring so I decided to leave them for now, It is definitely a game I will return to to maybe do some of the side quests. Great experience for anybody with a well optimised engine which will run well on budget cards. Well worth a buy if you're looking for stealth or rough and tumble gameplay.

-This is a review of the game leading up to the end of the main story. Any missions or equipment that is unlocked after the final act is not in my opinion whatsoever that must be judged yourself or with others reviews.

Recommended

Posted: 5 April
UPDATED REVIEW (original below) - After getting more playtime under my belt, there are a few redeeming factors in this game. First and the most important is the visuals. No one can deny that this is a beautiful game with scenery that feels so real to the time frame it's based in and the characters movements and emotion in the cut scenes. I've always loved AC games because they kinda feel like I'm watching a movie and I personally think this game captures that as well. Another is the story, while I still feel like the plot is less than, when you are playing the characters one on one in the story line I think it has some great moments that really grab at your attention and interest. The side quests are pretty fun, especially the ghost hunting with Charles Dickens, I love the characters, and while most the fighting is repetitive it still serves it's purpose. I've also gone further into the Jack the Ripper DLC and have nothing bad to say honestly, that is a great addition and probably the only reason I'd buy the game. The bad points that still surface are the glitches. Whether it's the game not registering a chest I've already picked up, having to redo multiple fights because my moves weren't being registered like they should, NPCs glitching through walls or just not being there in some cut scenes.. yeah it doesn't make the game look great and it makes it difficult to play. So should you buy it? Yeah why not. If you love this time frame like me, I do believe it'll give you that personal experience of living through it. And again, if you're wanting to finish the AC library I do believe that while this isn't the best one, it is not the worst either. Definitely wait until it's on sale though, I would never buy this game full price.

Only a few hours into playing and already it disappoints me compared to other AC games. It's glitchy in all aspects, has some wacky controls that have registering issues when commanded, and honestly lacks a good backbone of a story. I love some of the characters but most of the dialogue between the twins is just bad jokes or fighting so far and it takes away from what is going on around them. I have enjoyed the Jack the Ripper add on more than the main game. If you love AC then I do think it's worth it just so you can say you've played it and know the lore, but I won't be doing any extra play throughs when finished with the game.

The combat is more versatile than previous games, when it plays out well it plays out well but sometimes it can get frustratingly weird, if you got bonked on your head by the cops you'll know what I mean.

Graphics are impressive but do keep in mind of the quite common stutter bug this game has, to fix that add the code to turn of nvidia hariworks framerate thingy(just google how to do it) and that smoothens the game out, also you can turn off the fog for more clarity.

I would rate the game 3.5/5, it is still a decent game for the fans but not as good as Black Flag or the initial games in the sense of story. As far as mechanics go it is more fun to play out than the older games but at the cost of some annoying glitches and cheesy story points.

Loved:
-The gorgeous London recreated with sights to see, probably one of my top favorite settings in an open world game.

-Costume design.

I would rate the game 3.5/5, it is still a decent game for the fans but not as good as Black Flag or the initial games in the sense of story. As far as mechanics go it is more fun to play out than the older games but at the cost of some annoying glitches and cheesy story points.

ChillBanana
310 products in account
0
1 person found this review helpful 0

Recommended
46.5 hrs on record
Posted: 13 July, 2017
Fun game with more personality than AC: Unity, it largely streamlines the better aspects of the franchise's gameplay and doesn't feel as bloated as some prior games. The ability to switch between main characters is a welcome addition, though the character's motivations in cutscenes still feel schizophrenic when contrasted with actual gameplay.

The setting of Victorian England is excellent (so was the French Revolution but Unity managed to make that bland somehow!), the gang warfare aspects are fun even if largely a repeated template and the side-character memories spice things up a little. The game also doesn't mind having a little fun at its own expense, like characters rolling their eyes at the big self-important speeches targets make post-assassination. Unfortunately the main villain isn't particularly memorable (there is a VERY memorable side-villain who shows up very late in the game and is unfortunately quickly killed off) nor does he feel particularly effective or dangerous regardless of what the game insists on telling you.

The modern day framing is reduced as much as possible without removing it entirely (please just remove it entirely) and remains as uncompelling and uninteresting as before. The "witticisms" of the tech character seems to have been toned down somewhat, though it remains a mildly frustrating presence while trying to read up on the history of characters/locations in the database you assemble throughout the game. Being a ubisoft game, the collectibles are overkill and maps don't exist for a couple of items, making it an exercise in frustration to find yourself 1-2 items short of clearing a section of the map. The game frequently presents you with "helix points" for doing things. I have no idea what helix points are and since it didn't seem to affect the game in any noticable way I didn't bother looking it up.

Basically this is a fun Assassin's Creed game. It doesn't do anything particularly revolutionary or change up the franchise much (Black Flag remains the high watermark in that regard) but it does what it does very well. There's a lot of the same problems from previous games, but they've been reduced to some degree while what is fun has been polished quite nicely. Definitely worth picking up in a sale.

Posted: 5 April, 2019
Great game, well worth it's price on sale!

PC port is good. 1440p/High @ 30fps very stable (only drops on cutscenes) with i5-8300H, 8GB RAM and GTX 1050Ti.
No crashes or issues, it runs perfectly. Need to lock at 30fps with RTSS though. 60fps is impossible with this CPU.

It's a good AC game with enhanced mechanics over Unity. It keeps the good stuff and improves the rest while still keeping the traditional Assassin's Creed experience. This time around the interesting part is that we have 2 protagonists. Jacob is more classic-style and focused on combat while Evie is more focused on stealth approach. You can change the characters anytime for side content. Story overall is not good but it's in the Assassin's Creed franchise standards.

Map size is not the biggest but it's enough for a current-gen experience with plenty of side stuff to have fun. It took around 24 hours to beat the story and complete every side missions in this game (no collectibles, only missions/free the city).

Combat mechanics and parkour are way better than AC4 and it is about the same as Unity. It's also much faster because now you have a rope to climb faster, making free running and climbing more fun.

Great game and probably the best classic Assassin's Creed game, I had a lot of fun with it.

Recommended
27.0 hrs on record
Posted: 12 January, 2021
Superior to Unity in every way and the best traditional Assassin's Creed game to date.
I was biased to believe that it was bad, but it ended up improving on everything that Unity stood for.

This is the truest Assassin's Creed to date. Both side content and main story missions are filled with assassin sandbox objectives and it's a delight to be able to be a proper assassin, scoping the area, picking guards 1 by 1 and outgunned and outnumbered, but prevailing over the opposition. Child Labor, Templar Huts, Gang Strongholds, Cargo Steal - encourage you to be the best, to recon, to utilize tools, to be a badÐ°ss. You can kill gang leader before actual gang war. Ziplines are a welcome addition, the cover system is better.

The assassinations are better than Unity. All of the Assassination story missions present unique settings and opportunities, "Unique Kill" is great, there are barely any fail states. Lambeth Asylym, Buckingham Palace, Bank of England, Alhambra Music Hall - so many well designed missions.

The new combat system is tough to start getting used to, but once you level up and start using Multi Kills, it becomes very satisfying. I even completed fight clubs deliberately, to farm Quadra Kills.

The music is very good. Free exploration and stealth infiltration music - masterfully crafts the atmosphere, impressively interesting timbres and arrangements. The soundscape of industrial London, with all sorts of alarms, horns, whistles, metal and machines feels very inspired and a must to experience.

The story has it's bad moments and I was planning to rant about it a lot, but no, I ended up being completely satisfied, the framework in which it operated was very good. (kill 7 henchmen and the main bad guy after)

I really liked this game - but unfortunately it's not a good game. The game is bloated. This game is a slog and chore to grind up to 100% with zero payoff. MOST of the side content is amazing, plainly good - this game's problem is that there is just too much of it! By the 10th hour of going through only side content, there won't be anything new for you to see. The collectibles are as terrible as in every Assassin's Creed game.

After I completed the final mission, the game has yet unlocked more side content for me to do - Queen Victoria missions. You really can't help, but need to all the hard work not to go to waste, can you Ubisoft?

Bell, Dickens, Darwin, Victoria, Nightingale - none of them are of any value to the actual plot, most of them are present for like 1 mission in the entire storyline. They couldn't shoe horn Karl Marx into the story missions, and so his side content is unlocked abruptly and without introduction.

The game is designed around the idea of "take famous person -> make protagonists run errands for them"

The races are bad, probably the lowest point of the game. Need for Speed Underground levels of rubber-banding on opponents part.

cyie
521 products in account
0
15 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
39.2 hrs on record
Posted: 2 January, 2017
By far the best AC game since Black Flag.

I wasn't expecting much from this game and to be honest, when I heard the addition of a "Grapel Gun" was going to be a thing I sort of thought "Uhhh so, short cut the parkour element of the series? Well ok.." and had even lower hopes but in playing this game I was pleasantly surprised and as for the grappel? You'll often find you only use it in cases of emergency (Such as needing to scale something quickly while persuing a fleeing target)

Grpahically it's pretty standard for the series but that's not a bad thing. Industrial London is absoloutely beautiful and it's one of the few cities that actually feels alive in a video game. It's very heavily populated which makes from some reallly fun gameplay and exploration.

Gameplay wise it is also pretty standard except they've clearly moved as far away from the whole "social stealth" gimick of earlier games and just plunged head first in to full on stealth. Proper stealth is now a completely viable and worthwhile option. The parkour has been improved greatly. Navigating is really smooth and you can use the grappel gun to cross the street via zipline without ever having to break your little free running experience.

Before in earlier games you'd be running across rooftops then suddenly find you had no choice other than to drop on to the street. This made tailing people pretty damn annoying but in this one the grappel gun solves this problem. you're no longer forced to drop to the ground. You can remain on rooftops all sneaky like.

Story wise it's excellent but if you come here for the present day type story you will be dissapointed as there is very little present day story in this game (Which I prefer to be honest) instead it focuses solely on London in the 1800 and the adventures of Jacob and Evie.

Speaking of, they are brilliant characters who contrast each other very well. Evie is quite clearly the better character of the two and I often found myself wanting to get her missions completed before I even touched jacobs. Her interactions with the other characters remind me of the way Ezio interacted with people in AC2 and that's never a bad thing. Jacob on the otherhand has a very kenway like approach to things.



It's an awesome game and I highly reccomend it. Hate the whole microtransaction crap they have going on though. You don't need to engage in any of it but the fact that this story focused, single player game has microtransactions shows what kind of â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ Ubisoft is trying to move toward.

I have to say, I very much enjoyed this game. The aesthetics are great and the world feels very lived in. It truly feels like a glimpse into industrial era London, and the music goes well with it (at least most of the time, had one weird glitch once...). The gameplay is what I've come to expect from the past AC titles, along with a decent story and characters. Evie and Jacob are very archetypal, but it never seemed to bother me, and I enjoyed both of them (although I played as Evie primarily). There are some neat additions like the hookshot that make for some fun as well. The game isn't without flaws, and suffers from some of the same problems as Unity (although far, far, FAR less). I didn't feel like the flaws took away from my experience though, and were only ever minor things.

The DLC were all decent additions to the game, however I don't think any of them would be worth anywhere near the standard price. Absolutely buy on a deep discount. The game, overall, is a solid entry in the series and caps off the original AC style well. Now I'm on to Origins.

Posted: 17 January, 2016
The previous Assassin's Creed Title: Rogue put us in the role of an assassin turned templar. This game takes us back to the roots of being an assassin and fighting the pesky templars.

However, major changes! Don't worry, no story spoilers here. Just the game dynamics!

You take on the role of two assassins, Jacob and Evie Frye. Yes, you read it right. Two assassins!

Don't like Jacob or simply tired of male characters? Play Evie! She is quite the blast. There are missions that require you to be a specific character, but in free roam you can be whoever you want and switching betweem them is as easy ad 1-2-3.

The first time I saw the game world. I said, "WOAH!". Well, perhaps I shouted it...I don't know. I did have a literal nerdgasm though. The recreation of London is phenomenal! Wait until you guys see the Buckingham Palace or climb the Big Ben. It's simply fabulous.

The combat is still nice and easy with a mix of firearms and throwing knives. Both Evie and Jacob have a set of skills they can train and they have 2-3 unique abilities exclusive only to them. Whatever you decide to level make sure you grab lockpicking for opening chests! The locked ones are a guarantee to acquire schematics for cool weapons and garments.

Fighting is fluid, climbing has never been easier, voice acting is great, the story line feels flushed out, and the world is marvelous. However, it's not about being the assassin anymore as it is about saving London. The player will fight rival gangs, free children from corrupt factory owners, and save city district by district from the "Blighted" rule of the Templars.

I wish you luck on your adventures and I hope you enjoy this game as much as I did for every second of playing it.

Recommended
28.3 hrs on record
Posted: 22 November, 2015
Syndicate runs well for a Ubisoft game, UPlay has been updated and redefined so now it's much more like using origin, it's less clunky and frustrating to play a Ubisoft game on PC now, well for me at least.

The gameplay feels like a tradional AC game with the addition of a grappling hook so you can quickly make it from point A to point B. The melee combat is much faster paced and the takedowns are incredibly over the top, I bashed a guy in the head with a cane and he did a full flip and then I hit him again to kill him, they're cool looking none the less but it's a little too over the top at times.

Jacob and Evie are probably my all time favorite protagonist's out of all AC games, I played Rogue and I felt that Shay was an amazing character to play as but running around as Jacob or Evie is much more enjoyable this time around.

The customization is nicely done, they still offer micro transactions like they did in Unity but it feels much less forced now, I've been able to quickly get the equipment I want by just playing the game the way I want to, I don't feel forced to buy a package of in game money so I can upgrade my weapon. So that's good!

One thing that bothers me is the lack of inventory and equipment, you're only able to equip your weapon in full combat as well as the hidden blade which really bothers me, the whole point of the cane sword is to have a weapon concealed in an average cane but you don't even get to see it! You fight someone and then you take the cane out of your coat pocket and then put it back in after the fight is over, I would like to be able to walk around with the cane hanging out in my hands like in the screenshots but nope. Maybe they'll fix it in an update.

All in all Syndicate is great, it runs well, it's gameplay is great, London is incredibly fun to be in, the characters are well rounded and have a good sense of humour, and the addition of being able to walk around the city with a gang following you is very cool, feels much like Peaky Blinders the game (Great show if you haven't watched it already!)

Not Recommended
31.4 hrs on record
Posted: 7 July, 2017
It's not a terrible game, but it definitely did not mark a real positive veering to get back on the right track after the disaster that was Unity.

CONS:

There's just a few issues with the game that for me point to it being a sup-par game, especially when compared to other games in the series:

-Laziness regarding world-refinement: One of the most striking examples of laziness in the game are the guard sentry boxes that you'll see at Buckingham Palace, Wellington Barracks, etc. If you look at the top of the box, if your facing the front, you will see the insignia 'EIIR' which is the royal insignia for Queen Elizabeth the second. It baffles me how this even made it into the game. Ubisoft got the it right for post boxes, giving them the 'VR' insignia, Queen Victoria's. Anyways, point stands that it was a very lazy mistake, that could have easily been avoided.

-The game just crams in every historical figure that was around at the time and suggests almost no conflict of interests.
'Oh Yes, Karl Marx, I shall escort you to your trade union, not until after I finish an odd job for Queen victoria though.'
This seriously damages the dramatic value of the game. If the protagonist is just a 'yes-man' for every mission-giver then the game seriously just becomes Historical Figure Hunter 5. Even Assassin's Creed 3 had Connor standing up to allies like Washington, Samuel Adams, etc, and it made for an interesting story by casting scrutiny on colossal figures in history.

-Syndicate has reverted back to the old style of Templar, the textbook Moustache-Twiddling villain who is unmistakably evil. This made for a really watered down plot. Ending was terrible.

-Rope Launcher ruining what was half of the fun in the first few games of the series.


Okay, I feel bad so I will highlight some of the PROS:

-Combat is more challenging challenging, thought lack of weapon choice (being limited to 3 types of melee weapon) does make it dull. Though I guess it wouldn't be historically accurate to travel around with a large heavy axe in 1868.

Mysdax
135 products in account
0
1 person found this review helpful 1

Recommended
103.3 hrs on record
Posted: 8 September, 2021
STORY

Relatively short for an Assassin's Creed game of such scales - London has to be one of the biggest locations in the entire series (before Origins, Odyssey and Valhalla), yet the story is too short for it. Starrick isn't as charismatic as other main antagonists of the series (compared to Germain and Haytham), and in this one we're playing as already trained assassins. Nonetheless, both Jacob and Evie have interesting personalities, and even if they have barely any character development, they're still interesting to play as and I didn't skip a single cutscene with them. The most boring character, unfortunately, has to be Henry. He's just... there.

WORLD

As I said, London is one of the biggest maps that Assassins ever Creeded. And it's interesting to traverse around it, I found myself just looking at the character walking around at a slow pace, or some dafties playing cricket in the backyard. London feels alive thanks to all the carriages and trains. And surprisingly, every region has its own taste to it.

GAMEPLAY

Yes, ranking system exists. And yes, it works as a really good way of implementing difficulty. It's up to you if you want to make the game easier or keep it purposefully harder. Nonetheless, you still insta-kill if you use the hidden blade.
I've got no beef with Ubisoft Towers and I honestly wish they kept this gimmick, it really shows what you can do in the world and where you can go.

COMBAT

Different weapons! Bet we won't see that again.
For real, it's nice to see an assassin wield something other than a sword for once, and each weapon has its use. Throwing knives are still nice, but the lack of sleep darts makes the game a bit more difficult. Pistols are great for open combat. The combo system is also a nice touch, especially combined with some of the skills from the tree.

SOUND

The sound design is great. My only issue is the soundtrack itself - it's easily the weakest one on the series. Too much quick strings, mostly without any other instruments on the background. An interesting touch, but not fitting for Assassin's Creed game.

TECHNICAL

Surprisingly well-polished, compared to the previous game in the series. Granted, it still has some signature Ubisoft bugs related to NPC generation, but other than that - it's as smooth as an Ubisoft game can get.

CONCLUSION

Buy it when it's on discount. If you want to spend some free time walking around Victorian London - the game's for you.

Recommended
50.8 hrs on record
Posted: 2 May, 2021
Decent AC game but nothing special. Doesn't do much to step out of the bubble of the traditional ac format (unlike origins). Story is mediocre but serves its purpose in giving you a reason to beat up some Templars, and speaking of beating up Templars, the combat is serviceable and fun for the first few hours but gets pretty old, pretty quick. However stealth is great, many different ways to approach an encounter and has some decent AI as well. Parkour is good but isn't as relevant because of the grapple hook added to the game, which is fun but ultimately forces parkour to take the backseat. So if combat is decent, parkour is decent, and story is mediocre, what makes this game stand out? Well in my opinion, it's the world. The world has INCREDIBLE atmosphere and I rarely hear people talking about it. Synchronising on a viewpoint is so magnificent and is lifted up by the sounds of Victorian London sounding violins. Seeing all the horse carriages and factories emitting large clouds of smoke into the sky is so well done. Patrolling London at night has a sense of unpredictability and can feel quite dangerous. If there is one thing I am a sucker for in games, its the atmosphere, it adds to the immersion greatly and being immersed in a world is the main reason why I play so much single player games (and why I love the witcher 3, rdr2, and the ac series so much). You may not share my passion for the world in this game, but you should defiantly give it a try because I think it's the most underrated world in an AC game. But apart from that, it's just more AC with a few tweaks here and there.


7/10 Great world, meh gameplay.

Despite my initial grievances with the grappling hook to parkour across streets, the environment encourages its use through wide streets and large gaps between boat masts and building towers. I would consider the game a slight step down from Unity, but the characters are engaging and overall the game still captures the blend of history and fiction. The music in this game is amazing, which surprised me as I never found music to be a notable strength of the AC series. Advanced parkour mechanics from Unity are refined which is the best parkour mechanics in the series imo. Overall, I'd give it an 8/10, but I absolutely love the series until Odyssey so my review might be a little biased in favor of the game.

EDIT:
Having now completely 100% sync the main game I will say that this game sucks for completionists. Side characters such as Darwin and Dickens are great characters that should be more involved in the main campaign. But almost all associate activities are forgettable. The Duleep-signh activities are riddled with multiple breaking bugs i.e. quests completing before characters finish talking, getting GER'd into an infinite death loop until a reddit forum from 5 years ago told me how to exit this game breaking bug.

TLDR:
For a casual assassin's creed fan who enjoys the stories and characters this will be a great game. For a completionist that fights for every achievement and quest, this game will make you suffer more than any of the previous titles, it is just too oversaturated with mediocrity and grind.

60.8 hrs on record

Pros
- Amazing Graphics
- The facts, histories and the good view of the London
- New items: Grappling hook and throwing knife
- The combat and item upgrades
- The real Assassin's Creed game that has no naval ship battles in the whole game

Cons
- A lot of bugs encountered
- The story is not quite interesting than the previous games
- The story line is quite a bit short
- Other side quests are not also interesting
- The fighting mechanics is good or bad, still prefer the AC3 mechanics

The AC Syndicate's story is kind a boring and nothing memorable. It's like the creators set the Assassins as the good people and the Templars are bad people with nothing deep reason why they turned. Comparing this to AC3 story line and its side quest is far more interesting as you will know the real purpose of the Templars. What really interesting on this game is the future events after the World War 1 in London and the aftermath of the Frye twins.

Also, the long gameplay of this game might get you bored and not quite enjoyable. Compared to AC3 gameplay on side quest and forest biomes.

I'll rate this game of 7/10 and better to buy this game at below 50% discounted price.

35 products in account

Recommended
121.8 hrs on record
Posted: 24 July, 2020
This game is a massive improvement over unity

+ Having started playing this game the day after I finished Unity, this game craps all over Unity from the very first few minutes of play and shows up Unity for the massive turd that it is.
+ The parkour is better, much smoother. Small movements are possible again to edge into position. Your character will not jump up even on low crates unless you press the parkour up button.
+ The main characters have much more personality. The Frye twins play off each other brilliantly. In general, the writing is much better.
+ Proper side characters are back. Say hello to people like Charles Darwin and Charles Dickens.
+ As someone who lives close to London, it feels like a very believable rendition of London in the 19th century.
+ This is the closest Assassin's Creed ever gets to the brilliant AC2 trilogy. Not that I don't like the subsequent games (in fact I love Origins), but they take a different path. Syndicate is the closest feeling of fun you get from the AC2 trilogy.

= I'm not a big fan of the weapon and armour system in Syndicate (which is an extension of Unity's). It feels in between the more or less straight "worst to best" systems in the older games and the more full-on RPG system in later games, but the worst of both worlds. It feels limiting. However, it's a relatively minor gripe in the context of some of the worst element of the last few games in the series (like the awful parkour in the previous few games.

- Can't really think of any outright negatives to be honest, Syndicate is one of the best games in the AC series.

Recommended
60.2 hrs on record
Posted: 28 June, 2020
To begin with this review I must say that I've never been attracted to XIX century nor London. I really liked AC Unity (I played it in 2019, so almost no bugs) and I didn't have many expectations about this game because of what I said above. But from the start, I've been really really hooked on this game and I DEFINITELY RECOMMEND THIS GAME!!!.

I think the presentation of the story is marvelous, a few sequences to get how to control the characters and then boom, London! You can do whatever you want there. Personally, I liberated most of the city on sequence 4, and then Westminster on sequence 5 because of a necessary upgrade to achieve 100% on that mission. The story focus on one or two targets every sequence, which every one has its own perks to assassinate. I loved getting the unique kill opportunities. Also, the secondary objectives are really achievable. To me, that's positive, because it means I wouldn't get frustrated at every mission lol.

You also control 2 characters , and they have their own missions. I love them both, I feel they are very charismatic in their own way, and I like their story though the game. Jacob is more carefree and decides to liberate London while Evie is more thoughtful and decides to look for the piece of Eden there in London. I know some people have complained about the leveling system, but I think it's pretty good, I was at level 10 really early on the story and if you do every mission, you'll most likely get to level 10 very fast.

The only negative thing I've encountered is that I can't get into the cooperative missions, or whatever they are called, it always displayed an error message.

Overall, this game is sooo good in my opinion. I had low expectations because "meh, London", but I'm so in love with the city and the story that now I'm really curious and willing to travel there one day!

Not my favorite addition to the series, but it's a very visually stunning game and has a pretty decent storyline. The side objectives are usually interesting and kept me entertained after the main story's completion, and the collectibles aren't so numerous or hidden that they're annoying to hunt down. The audio is beautiful, the soundtrack is definitely one of my favorites in the AC series, and overall I had a good experience playing through this. I've gone through the story three times (once on PC, twice on Xbox), and I've yet to encounter any major glitches or bugs within the game. There are minor issues like carriages or people spawning in out of nowhere, but it's a big game and not everything can be perfect all the time. Overall, it's a good game if you enjoyed Unity's mechanics but wanted more stabilized controls, and if you liked keeping up with the general Assassin's Creed feel in games.

The game has to be played, I honesty grew attached to Jacob and Evie after playing the entire Campaign and the DLC's. The game itself stands out from the previous Assassin's Creed games because it introduces close combat and eliminates any swords.

A lot of people complained that Syndicate does not feel like previous Assassin's Creed because they introduced the Grappling Hook which made climbing so much more easier and rooftops are so much efficiently climbed. I honestly didn't think I will like it, but taking into consideration the setting and the period the game happened I honestly loved it.

Now the story was different from previous ones, the focus was not as much as before from both characters on the Items of Eden, only Evie that focused on them, but it had some really fun and interesting missions with Jacob. Overall I'd score this game at: 8/10

It's my personal opinion and I stand firm to it that it was an enjoyable game worth playing. Huge fan of the AC franchise players will enjoy this as much as I do.

The good: decent PC performance (unlike Unity), great visuals and artwork, fun story and side missions, two very likeable playable characters. New GTA-like carriage gameplay, if you're into that sort of thing.

The bad: Just about everything that's been wrong with AC since forever. Clunky combat, TONS of busywork and collect-a-thons, same models for just about every NPC you find, boring and obnoxious escort and follow missions.

If Myð¿ð¾cketHð°dMoneyð¸
661 products in account
0
1 person found this review helpful 0

Recommended
83.8 hrs on record
Posted: 12 December, 2015
Assassins Creed: Syndicate is by far my favourite game in the series.
This review is from the perspective of an avid AC fan.
GPU: GTX 970, CPU: i7-4790, RAM: 16GB
Current Playtime: 54 Hours

As much as I dislike Ubisoft's decision to publish a new AC game every year, this one in particular really shines as the best in a long time. The Victorian London setting brings a certain degree of comedy and sarcasm to each of the characters featured in the story. In turn this makes for an entertaining experience and leaves you begging for more.

The two new Assassins fit the game perfectly and are certainly inline with the likes of Ezio and the Kenways. The brother and sister relationship between the two make for great banter and bring variaty to the gameplay. Although at times it can feel like Jacob is the prefered Assassin in the story. Both are badass and deserve another game.

The game runs smoothly at a constant 60fps (that is with most 'Nvidea Gameworks' features disabled) and certainly outshines the performance of Unity. There are minor bugs here are there, but nothing to distract from the game world. To put it best, it's The Animus. It's not perfect by any means, however that's simply AC for you.

Ubisoft are taking a step in the right direction but it is another AC game. If that's what you're after, you'll love it as I have done. If you're looking for something different you may be a tad dissapointed (although London does offer it's own unique experience). I really hope that this amazing game isn't outshadowed by the shaky release of the previous game, Unity.

Pros:
- Victorian London (Vast open city with great detail)
- Interesting Combat (Fist to Fist, Kuncle Dusters, Canes)
- Playable Assassins (Jacob and Evie Frye)
- Interesting use of London (Queen Victoria, Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, Sherlock Holmes Outfit, Jack the Ripper)
- Collectables (Secrets of London are fun to find via Database Images)
- Villans are truly British.. I mean... Evil

Cons:
- Minor Bugs
- Clothing Physics (30 fps)
- Too Easy (For an experienced AC player)
- No Multiplayer


UPDATE: The Jack The Ripper DLC is really something amazing. However there does seem to be a large number of performance issues around it, which is a massive shame.

[C]hosen One
387 products in account
0
1 person found this review helpful 0

Recommended
86.0 hrs on record
Posted: 5 December, 2015
The game itself is fun, and a definite improvement over Unity in many ways - with the exception of some facial animations and lighting. The game itself runs fine: I get around 40 - 60 FPS in the open world (with no stuttering) on the high preset on an R9 280X, which is decent (could be better mind you, but I've played worse). There are some drawbacks, however: graphics settings are pretty limited (e.g. no anisotropic filtering, anti-aliasing is limited to nasty FXAA and MSAA combinations, can't turn off any of the post-process stuff), special/Gameworks graphics settings are nearly broken on Radeon (and apparently some Nvidia) cards and some cloth physics are limited to 30 FPS, which sounds anal as hell but you'll know exactly what I mean when you play it. But, overall, this is a solid port.

Good game. I like the story line so far, and i can say for sure that this is one of those storylines where you care about the main characters. So far i am not too happy about the combat system, but that is more like a personal opinion. Personally i prefer the old combat system, where everything was a little bit ''easier''. Syndicate takes Assasins creed to the next level, because the choices you make in combat does matter, and you can indeed end up dead if you choose wrong.

The Graphics are ok. Just like any other assasins creed game, i dont really see a big difference in graphics, but hey, that might just be me being stupid. My game did also end up crashing 1 minute into the game, but it did not happen again. Maybe this just had something to do with the launch. I am also getting a lot of loading lag spikes whilst driving a carriage, but i dont really prefer the carriage so it does not matter to me.

I will for sure finish the campaign and try to master the combat system so i can have some fun, but i dont see myself playing a lot of hours after the main story.

So as an assasins creed fan, is it worth buying?
Yes it is. You can for sure get a lot of hours of fun gameplay and interesting Main quests.

So is it worth getting today? Should i pay the full price?
I would say no. The game has some stuff that i simply not prefer and do not like compared to other assasins creed games. I suggest looking up some gameplay and story on youtube before buying the game for its full price.

So first off I'm a fan of this series and have completed almost all the games since the first, with the exception of Unity and Liberation. With that out the way, this game generally good. The Gameplay is fun, London(in all it's stinky, industrial age glory) is a lot of fun to run around in and the twins are mostly likable(Evie moreson the Jacob). Also, the hookshot basically allows you to be steampunk batman(and considering how wide some to the streets are and how tall some of the buildings are, this is quite welcome).

The game isn't without flaws though. The plot is mostly ok, to the point I can barely recall it and I beat it a few days ago. It pretty much boils down to "London has been a Templar city for a century, let's go take it back(and form a gang while we're at it)" and "They probably have a piece of eden, let's grab it before they do". Nothing you haven't already seen in this series a few times already.

Much of the game invovles retaking the city district by distirct by doing various activities and then fighting an area boss to claim the borrough to make money and work your way up the skill/upgrade tree(and yo need to do this somewhat because there are levels attached to various activieis). There's a sequence for each Templar gang boss ending with essentially a complex(of a sorts) assasination mission, which are the few bits that felt like they had a lot more effort put into them(with optional objectives to make it easier to reach the target unseen).

A minor nitpick but one nonetheless is that the game feels like it's not taking any risks, perfering to play it safe in pretty much every way. Nothing is really innovative on the gameplay front(other then the hookshot) and nothing in the game really forwards the narrative much, either in the present or in the past. At best, what we see is that the Assasins by 1868 are already pretty screwed in that while the Templars inserted themselves deep into captalism so that killling them causes the system to break down(and plenty of collateral damage with it), while the Assasins are pretty much limited to "Kill Templars, break their toys, grab a piece of eden and call it a day" in their strategy. It's really no wonder they're hurting so badly 150 years later.

So in all, it's fun and it's a great recreation of London. Just don't expect anything groundbreaking as far as gameplay or plot.

DukeSkyewalker
307 products in account
0
1 person found this review helpful 0

Recommended
80.6 hrs on record
Posted: 19 December, 2020
Alright, this is going to be a big one, but I'll try to be as complete as possible. I've just hit 100% on both the main game and the Jack the Ripper DLC, so while it's still fresh on the memory. Some of it is in spoiler text. Look at these bits at your own peril.

What I really liked:
- The world opened quickly and is, from that point on, fully accessible. There are conquest activities that are usually interesting and well made, and plenty of collectibles.
- Dreadful Crimes (DLC) was very well thought out and definitely recommended if you liked the murder mysteries in AC:U. They've improved by miles, I figured them all out from the clues and none of the solutions felt incredible farfetched.

What I liked:
- I've played through the game as Evie, except when forced to play another character. This is because the game has implemented a smart system where either of the twins has a unique playstyle. Jacob favours combat and Evie favours stealth. I like being stealthy, so I picked Evie. Also, during the game, Jacob's only redeeming quality is his top hat and that's never a good thing.
- The main story is entertaining, but the end is super predictable if you've played any AC game before. It ends just like all the other ones. No specific spoilers, but none are needed. I don't care very much for the 'witty' arguments Evie and Jacob seem to be continuously having, but I can see how others might enjoy that type of dialogue as well.
- Freerunning has definitely improved, but the characters still stick to the Arno school of never giving up on ledges. When you're trying to move fast and precise, the system seems to be fully intent on making the wrong calls when it comes to freerunning, but I suppose this is to be expected from the AC series by now.
- Jack the Ripper (DLC) introduces a mildly interesting new concept of using fear as a weapon. You play through brief sections of the game as the bad guy, which might be seen as enjoyable to some players (but not me, I just powered through to get back to enjoyable bits). The DLC also adds a serious amount of content, which will make it worth your money.

What I disliked:
- Jack the Ripper (DLC) has an unsurprising story that harps on the concept that "even assassins can be evil", as if we didn't know. This is meant to further an arbitrary "we're all the bad guy" narrative that this series didn't need. The unfortunate bit is that the big plot twist is presented literal seconds after the DLC starts, nothing else is surprising.
- The Last Maharaja (DLC) is a poorly thought out section of the game with minigames that are unnecessary and an entire drunk section that is neither clever nor funny. Besides this, the whole side story will at the end feel like a complete waste of time. Would not recommend.
- Races are n o n e s e n s e - aren't required for 100%, so I skipped them all but one (to try it).
- Jack the Ripper (DLC): 

What I hated:
- The Dickens and Darwin conspiracy DLC was immensely disappointing and frankly a waste of time and effort. Strongly do not recommend.
- I had several crashes and soft locks for no reason. I would have carriages drive off even though it had no driver. Dead guys would block mission progression by claiming they were alive (but are on the ground, quite dead, but alive, but unkillable). I had a random guy panic drive off with a carriage that had a mission vital corpse in it (as part of the mission). More crashes. I had audio glitches where suddenly no voice lines were spoken. All in all, I think during the time I played, I encounted 10 to 20 serious bugs and it's not a good look for a game with this type of budget.
- Huge downside for what I personally hate the most in video games. Getting beaten in a cutscene. 

Would recommend!
All in all, I'd say this game is a solid game to play in the AC series. It's enjoyable and certainly lives up to the AC formula.
